content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												Rayman Legends is quite possibly the best 2d platformer released in the past 10 years.It’s the follow up title to Rayman Origins (also a great game) and if you missed it, 40 of the stages from Origins have been included in Legends as additional re-mastered content.It features over 120 different stages each with varying atmosphere, amazing music, and plenty of hidden collectibles. Each of the levels are hand drawn and beautiful to look at. Despite not being overly impressive on a technical level, Rayman uses a timeless style. While games like Crysis 3 probably won’t look that great 10 years from now, Rayman Legends will no doubt retain its charm.The game also has multiple characters to choose from along with a host of unlockables. There are underwater stealth missions, time trials, and even musical stages where you jump to the rhythm of remixed popular songs. The inclusion of daily and weekly challenges allows you to compete with your friends, adding tons of re-playability.If you enjoyed classic 2d platformers like Super Mario World and Donkey Kong Country, you should check out Rayman Legends as it’s the closest thing to them in this day and age.For a more detailed review, here’s a video my friend and fellow reviewer Trent uploaded:


Analog Reviews: Rayman Legends 
A Video of Rayman Legends
By: [AReV]Nomed

			Our Analog Review of Rayman Legends Written by: Trent and Valente Video Editing: Valente Please like and subscribe for more reviews, gameplay, and discussions!		


Rayman Legends also made our list for The Top 35 Games of the Generation. If you’re interested in seeing how it stacks up, check out:


YouTube™ Video: Analog Reviews: The Top 35 Games of the Generation (2006-2013)

content:
Posted: March 16, 2015
												Rayman Legends is a truly special game. Following the fantastic reboot of Rayman Origins, Legends surpases it in every way possible. The tight controls and superb level design makes gameplay smooth and fluid. Every death feels like a fault of your own and not the cause of a cheap obstacle or bad game design. Add to this the best visuals and art direction of any platformer ever (yes, including Trine 2), and you have a recipe for greatness. The UbiArt engine is able to produce such lush and wonderful artwork that it's hard not to stop at stare.As for content, this game has more than enough. Boasting a sizeable amount of main stages as well as Origins redone. Throw in the time trials and daily challenges, this game will surely satisfy any platformer fan.Although it may seem hyperbolic, I believe that I can say with certaintly that Rayman Legends is the finest platformer that I have ever played. It's the complete package. If you are a fan of the genre at all you owe it to yourself to pick this title up.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2015
												I'm going to start this review off by saying the only negative thing about Rayman Legends is Uplay, which if you haven't yet experienced it is basically the worst thing since the invention of the Vuvuzela. That said, I'm not even going to let Uplay hold me back from giving this game the amazing review it deserves. If you like platformers, you're going to love Rayman Legends. Simply said, it's one of the best platformers ever made and,  as someone who really loves platformers, I don't say that lightly. The artwork is beautiful, the soundtrack is incredible, and the game is just non-stop un-adulterated fun from stop to finish that you'll have a hard time putting it down. I logged more time into this game that I've ever put into any game short of Pokemon Silver version before I'd even realized I'd been so long. The amount of content that this game has to offer is astounding, especially considering almost all of it is utterly fantastic. Normally I'd give the message to boycott anything and everything that runs through Uplay but - just this once - I'll have to make an exception, because if you don't play this game you're missing out on something truly wonderful.

Posted: November 25, 2013
												one of the best platformers ever, puts Rayman origins to shame, this game has tons of extras to unlock. there are some amazing classic hit songs in some stages (won't spoil the surprises on you ;) ), the score is awesome and the art style is top notch, high production values all around.in case you didn't play Rayman Origins, the game is basically run from point A to point B to finish the stage, of course there are many hidden secrets in every stage and many things to collect to be able to unlock the other stages and progress through the game, it has a lot of variety and always interesting that you won't be able to put the controller down, there are many things that will spice up the game like in some stages you need to run as fast as possible to finish, some stages you will have a companion to help you out by raising up platforms or cutting ropes for you..etc.the main game tends to be a little easier than origins but it still lots of fun and there are many challenges to be had if you want to, there are also a few stages from origins that made it to this gamethe multi-player co op is frantic and funny as in origins, you will be laughing all the time at the crazy things that you can do when playing it with 3 other playersand then there is the mini game called Kung Foot, a crazy football game which requires you to slap or kick the ball and make it hit your opponent's goal, it might sound simple but it is really fun and you might get a lot of hours just playing this mini game.well i think that should be enough to make you buy it or at least give it a try, it really is amazing and it is really scary how much content this game has and if you are a fan of platformers, believe me you will enjoy this game for sure

content:
Posted: June 7, 2016
												I love Rayman franchise. I admire the main hero since the first game, which was released back in 1995 and simply named 'Rayman'. The games were always very colorful and beautiful. I truly enjoyed 3D games like 'Rayman 2: The Great Escape' and 'Rayman 3: Hoodlum Havoc'. They took a lot of hours of my life and I remember helping my cousin to beat them. Every single time Rayman games amazed me with great soundtrack, great gameplay and gorgeous characters.'Rayman Legends' is no exception, it's very similar to 'Rayman Origins', but I dare to say that it's easier than Origins. Why? You can collect everything without much effort. Lums are quite easy to get in a first try, the same goes with Teensies. I still love this  game though. It's beautiful beyond measure. the art is truly breathtaking. The same goes with music, it's really catchy and I found myself humming to it quite often. Daily challenges are nice addition and they keep you busy, even after beating the main story. It's a pleasant game and I can't wait for the next Rayman's adventures. Hopefully, next time we'll see them in 3D, because till this day one of my favourite games is 'Rayman 2: The Great Escape'.To sum up, 'Rayman Legends' is truly enjoyable, not too hard but still a must have for platform games fans, and what is more important: for Rayman fans, just like me.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												I have beat this game multiple times on console (don't hurt me), and I can easily say that this is one of the best platformers ever...hands down! Whenever people hear "greatest platformer ever" people always point at the original Mario games, Super Mario Galaxy, etc. However, this easily joins among their ranks.  This game is a breath of fresh air in the platformer genre. Along with its counterpart Rayman Origins (which I have also beat), they are both really refreshing platformer games because of their unique style, in graphics, gameplay, and level design.  Firstly, the game is visually stunning. The game uses an engine called the "UbiArt" engine, which is used to easily animate any image. The animations in this game are flawless given the many different movements that Rayman can use. Plus, the game feels INCREDIBLY smooth, and there are no visual flaws whatsoever. If I was to ever to die in this game, I cannot fault the game for choppy frame rate... I always blame myself! Speaking of which, the game has a difficulty balance that can accomodate both new players and old players. Some levels can be a breeze, but then others you can die A LOT, especially some of the later levels.  The level design is really good. Like most platformers, each world typically has a "theme". In my personal opinion, I believe that the "Fiesta de Los Muertos" world in Rayman Legends is the best, clearly because the level design is so great in every single level (if you play the first level at the world, you will see exactly what I mean). What a lot of platformers truly fail at achieving is creating MEMORABLE levels, and Rayman Legends has at least a few memorable levels that will be stuck in your head. Even the boss battles are really great!   The gameplay is also really addicting, with plenty of different moves to learn. This can range from a series of simplistic punches, all the way to cartwheels (a slightly more advanced move). While the objective is to complete a level, there is also a ranking for each level to grab a both a certain number of lums and "teensies". Lums, unlike the last game, are accumulated and can be used to unlock new variants of characters. Plus, lucky tickets unlock plenty of different things, including updated Rayman Origins levels!   ...and the multiplayer...oh my....the multiplayer is GOLDEN!!!! This game easily has the most fun local multiplayer in a long while! The multiplayer is perfect for anybody, whether you want to play seriously or if you want to troll your friends. :) Another memorable part of the game, even though it is not as prominent, would be the soundtrack. The soundtrack really compliments the game in different ways, and I had a couple of tunes stuck in my head. Overall, the game can last you quite awhile, maybe about 15-20 hours to complete everything (depending on how good you are). What can also add to the length would be the daily and weekly challenges, where you can REALLY hone your skills. There are a few flaws, given the overall grand scheme of things, but hardly hold this game back from sheer greatness. I think that there should  have been more minigames along with "Kung Foot" because "Kung Foot" isn't necessarily my favorite part of the game. Also, I think that there are also too many "clone" characters (variants of Barbara in particular). To whomever might read this review, I would not even hesitate getting this game. Play it and love it! You won't regret it!

number of helpful: 22 of 30 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												Rayman Legends is just so much better than Origins. I remember talking, erm.. not so positive,.. about Origins. aside from the wonderful, colorful graphics. Well, let me say that Legends is a bigger and better game in every way; customization, unlockables (oh man, they keep on coming), secrets; there seems to be much more variety this time around and I couldn't recommend this game more.There are 6 worlds to be completed, with the last one being more of a bonus world. Each world has about 8 to 10 levels, and each level could you take at least 5 minutes to complete. So it's a big game. Add even more secret and unlockable levels to that number and you know why it's called Legends. Each of the first 5 worlds end with a musical level where you just run, punch and avoid enemies based on the music. It's brilliant and it works very well. In general there's much more variety gameplay wise as well, with the aforementioned musical levels but there are also stealth levels, and levels where you have to rely on a (CPU controlled) co-op partner.The animations and graphics are top notch. Rarely have I been as impressed with 2D visuals as I've been with the last few Rayman games. No words can describe how this game looks and plays, you really have to witness it for yourself. This is art !By the way, the boss fights aren't as frustrating as the ones in Origins. There was only one boss that, in my opinion, was more of a trial-and-error boss fight, the rest of them could easily be beaten the first time around, if you pay enough attention.Rayman Legends surprised me in a big way and I'm saddened to hear that it didn't sell all that well. It has tons of content, so much even that most games look empty in comparison.Buy it. Cherish it. Love it. Play it. But, more importantly, enjoy it. How can this game not put a smile on anyone's face ?[Rating: 92/100]

number of helpful: 14 of 19 people (74%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												This is what sequels should be all about. Taking mechanics that worked from the first title and buffing them to a mirror finish, and then introducing new ideas to make it original. For me, Origins was a really, really fun and solid game and a great return to form for the Rayman franchise. I've sunk many hours (three digits) into it and, despite not being the completionist type, have been pushed to try quite hard to do so by it's captivating art and great soundtrack, plus pile of content. With Legends, Ubisoft has managed to recreate this gem, but better. It's as simple as that.The UbiArt engine is slick at all times and always stable, the game is even prettier then the first and, somehow, even more tuneful. I haven't anything to complain about yet, except perhaps that it's not occasionally as brutal as Origins in spots, but there's always plenty more in the game, and I haven't even mentioned the online challenges yet where the player competes against a global leaderboard.If you like platformers, you'll probably love this game. It's fast, it's competitive and is sensibly integrated into online challenges, and doesn't suffer very much from being originally WiiU exclusive. It's my favorite game of 2013 (previously a title given to Revengeance), and a perfect 10 in my books.I do recommend picking up Origins before this one if you're a newcomer to the franchise, though. You will simply be missing out otherwise and it has come down drastically in price.

number of helpful: 8 of 8 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												I love platformer games.  They're such a nostalgia blast, taking me back to the old days where I was parked on the living room floor, 5 ft. from the TV trying master that epic double jump without falling in the hole for the 10th time in a row.  Rayman Origins came along and proved that that old school platforming action could still be viable, fun and challenging.  Now, Rayman Legends has managed to come along and actually improve on the foundation that Origins laid! Rayman Legends packs a ton of fun in one single package.  You have unlocks to collect, in the form of lums, characters, monsters and even old Origins levels.  You have challenging platformer action.  You have varied platformer action!  You have a great sense of humor.  You have a great art style to make it all shine.  It's really great.  Sometimes, games of these types reach a point where the game becomes too difficult.  It makes the experience nothing but frustrating and then the fun falls off fast.  Even Origins suffered from this from time to time.  In Legends, they've managed to find a perfect balance in the difficulty.  Most maps are challenging, without becoming anger inducing.  You might have to take two or three tries and a particular jump, but the pattern will click.  These types of games can also suffer from repetition, but Legends break that up as well.  You'll find the puzzle style changing from level to level, even within the same groups, keeping the game feeling fresh and entertaining. Beyond all the platformer action, I'm really impressed with the style and art direction going on in the game.  The end levels in each section doing something really great in how the tie in the games music with the game play.  This really stood out when I was playing a boss level to a Rayman-esque rendition of Ram Jam's "Black Betty".  As I came to obstacles, it because clear my jumps were timed to the drum beat of the song.  As you progressed, hearing that familiar back beat, you noticed the entire level was timed to it.  I couldn't help by smile and play the level over a couple times, just to marvel at the fun of it all.  They do this on every level and it's an attention to detail that you don't see to often!  So, should you snag Rayman Legends?  Yes.  Yes you should.  Don't even debate it.  Really, this game is worth it at any price.  Definitely bring your game pad though, I can't imagine pulling this game off with a keyboard and mouse.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												This game is impressively good. If you like Jump'n'Runs / Platformers you really should give it a try.  I managed to collect all possible 700 Teensies and I never had the feeling that I have to go on just to finish it, which sadly happens too often to me nowadays. I think it's easier than Rayman: Origins, which could be seen as one of the few cons. Especially the Back to Origins levels felt less challenging than the originals.The art-design is superior and the graphics look just great. It's crazy, bright and funny, but not too childish to be not appealing to mature audiences. Surely, you have to like that type of style and humor. The same goes for the sound, great work! The levels are greatly designed, not too long not too short and enough variety to keep it fun to play. It has challenging parts, which never are too hard and can always be mastered with some tries. Fortunately, the checkpoints are set really fair, perhaps making it a bit too easy.The music-levels are a highlight of the game, you run through a level to a song, while your jumping, attacking and the whole level architecture is timed to and built for the music.The daily and weekly challenges are nicely made and keep you going after you finished the rest of the game.I haven't played it with local multiplayer, but that also looks fun.While the game is such a great one and really conquered the throne of 2D-Jump'n'Runs for me, the only really big letdown is the usage of Uplay. Since you can buy it on Steam, why the hell do I have to use Uplay for online features. I can't even change my username! Sadly, I realized this after I connected Rayman: Legends and Farcry3 to it, with something like: username: uplayaccount … -.-Conclusion*Story: Well this is not the biggest part of the game, it's OK, nothing special but it doesn't need to be.*Gameplay: Great! Fluid controls, impressive varied levels, lots of stuff to unlock, online challenges*Graphics&Sound: Superior! I really love that style, not too childish but funny and crazyI give it 95 out of 100Side note: I played the game with maximum graphics fluidly and with a controller.

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												Coming from Rayman Origins I was expecting to see improvements from the old game, and boy was I right. For the most part it has better graphics than Origins, the controls are far more fluid and the addition of extra races, Murphy, and boxing glove powerup it really stood out beyond Origins, however, they removed the map system and went for a Mario 64 approach by using paintings to jump in. It's more organized this way but it doesn't make you feel like it's all in the same big world. For some reason I feel like the makers forgot this is a seperate game, as all the new stuff gets just thrown in your face without introduction/explanation, for instance the boxing glove. And just like that it also lacked quite a bit of story as there are 5 of the same nemesis all of the sudden for no reason. I was very happy to see some of the old characters from Rayman 1 return in Origins and was hoping to see some new ones in Legends as well. Sadly enough Murphy is all we got, no Ly, Clark, or robot pirates from Rayman 2. The nymphs from Origins were also nowhere to be found, instead we got random chicks (once again for no reason whatsoever). I will list in big lines the positive and negative aspects of the game:Positive:+ Smooth controls+ Amazing artstyle and graphics+ Broad variety of characters to play as+ Intense fast phased platforming+ Great amount of mobility+ Good amount of levels+ Increased difficulty as you progressNegative:- Close to no story- Lack of explanation for a lot of things in the game- Throws random things at you at parts- Becomes repetitive after a whileIn conclusion I recommend this game to all casual gamers who want some fun action packed gameplay and do not care about story. For the diehard Rayman fans I recommend Origins. For a part because it had much more story (the nymphs) and actual ending. For another part because it had more rememberable music, map and character evolution (Rayman gains new powers like wallrunning and fighting). Making it far more immersive. MrTheMarkoman out.

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Rayman Legends takes what was established in Rayman Origins and improves it. The vector graphics are back and look prettier than ever, there is the addition of a sidekick as well to help you get through some levels.There is a lot to do in this game, each level has 10 teensies to find (The little blue guys), as well as the challenge to find enough lums (The yellow flying guys) to earn the Gold trophy. There are also unlockable characters as well, collectable creatures, unlockable bonus levels from Rayman Origins (each has teensies and trophies to collect) and Time Trial levels as well. If you're a bit of a completionist like I am with these sorts of things, you'll have lots to keep you occupied. There is also the new music levels, which are very much like the chest chasing missions in Origins, completely timing based where you jump or attack in time with the music. These are excellently thought out and the timing is spot-on. These are a bit more forgiving than Origins' chest chasing missions though, having checkpoints rather than making you restart after each death.There are downsides though, this game is a console port and at times it shows, making some actions hard to perform using keyboard if you don't have nimble fingers. It is perfectly playable with the keyboard though and supports full key remapping (Which I suggest you do, I set mine to the Origins controls and it saved me a lot of trouble), but it may be easier to play using a controller. I can't say which is better, since I've only played using keyboard, although you can play one handed using keyboard, leaving your other hand free to do other stuff like eat a sandwich or write a book. It also doesn't really have much replayability, apart from the music levels which are awesome just to play occasionally, unless you are a big Rayman fan. Plus it only works through UPlay, which is not a bad piece of software but it does make things frustrating when you just want to get right into the game.Overall, this game is worth picking up, even at full price and the annoying DRM. Graphics are pretty and there is a lot to do. I'm really looking forward to the next game in the series,9/10

content:
Posted: March 6, 2016
												I have always had a soft spot for 2D platformers and this is probably my favorite of the genre at the moment. It has got bright colorful graphics, great controls, interesting level design and it offers a good level of challenge without being unfair or frustrating, something Rayman Origins often missed the mark on.The main part of game world is divided up into 5 different paintings, each with 9-10 levels based on different theme.  The paintings all end with a boss and a musical level, where the action in the level follows the background music. I loved the musical levels and I wish there were more of them. There is an extra unlockable painting that let’s you play the musical worlds again with added challenges, but it is basically the same level.The game has tonnes of content with invaded levels, daily/weekly challenges, and you can unlock most of the levels from Rayman Origins. You certainly get your money’s worth here.Honestly the only caveat for this game is Uplay...I have had issues with it in the past and I know many people continue to even today. To Ubisoft’s credit, over the last 3-4 years they have taken Uplay from being an unusable piece of malware to more of an annoyance. So let’s give them credit for that, I guess…My advice is just log into the Uplay application once, set it to offline and never, ever, touch it again.

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 15, 2016
Make your life legendaryRayman Legends is the sequel to the critically acclaimed Rayman Origins, with Legends taking what worked from Origins and refining it.Pros:You no longer have to unlock powers separately, meaning those who’ve already played through Origins can experience the entire moveset from the start.A fantastic artstyle that’s a lot more shinier and polished than Rayman Origins.A large pools of fun and great levels, backed by good level design.Additional modes like Challenges and Kung Foot help make the experience more replayable for both local co-op and singleplayer gamers!Surprisingly well optimised for lower-end computers!Nitpicks:The bonus “Creatures” element of the game is completely unnecessaryBeing locked out of certain levels in the challenges mode by a leveling system is frustratingOnline Multiplayer would had really made modes like Kung Foot more popular.The levels containing Murphy feel a lot more repetitive than normal, although at least they aren’t auto-scrollers.Cons:For a mostly local cooperative game, there’s no excuse for this to require Uplay., even if it has a lot of somewhat unnecessary online activities.The ReviewAs someone who grew up playing Rayman, I adored the return-to-form that was Rayman Origins, and Legends continue the trend with new levels, shinier graphics, and a ton of additional packed goodies.Rayman Legends is a mostly 2D platformer with a lot of collectathon elements, but it’s great to know that collecting all of the teensies is much a major requirement, which allows for speedrunning. There’s a huge amount of levels to play, and since you aren’t restricted in playing all of the worlds in order, you are given a lot more freedom to tackle levels! The return of 4-player co-op is good fun, although it quickly devolves the game into a chaotic mess, so completionists are better off playing alone (Which is still fun!).Gameplay for the most part, is as refined as Rayman Origins. The controls are responsive, and your moveset is versatile but simplistic enough that you are given a lot more control. It’s actually really difficult to talk about this game because of how perfect controlling the characters is. The physics, the button layouts, it just feels so natural. However, for keyboard players, I highly recommend picking up a controller to play this game, as with other platformers.The newest mechanic in Legends is of course, Murphy. By the press of a button, you can have him slap switches, tickle enemies, and cut ropes. For the most part, however, Murphy’s only included in some of the levels, which I’m perfectly fine with because Murphy feels heavily gimped from the Wii U version.As someone who’s 100% complete the game on Wii U, I’ve noticed huge differences between this version and the Wii U one as well. For one, there’s no 5 player co-op, or the ability to have complete control over Murphy. Both versions seem to trade one thing for another; The Wii U version allows complete control at the cost of not having direct control over your player in single-player mode, and the PC version lets you control your character, but have more limited control when it comes to Murphy. A good middle between the two would had fixed the problems, but both versions are stuck with the levels containing Murphy being either a slog or being quite the unintentional challenge when speedrunning/completing comes to play.The reason why Murphy levels feel weird in the PC version is because they were designed to be slow-paced, which makes them unintentionally more difficult now that you have full control over your character and can freely run.The game includes a wealth of side-modes to play, and while they aren’t anything to write home about, they are nice additions. Challenges make for a unique set of leaderboard challenges that’s constantly reset weekly (although a lot of the challenges are the same things from past rotations and can get repetitive), and Kung Foot is an insane blast to play. However, the addition of a XP bar to lock challenges and the “Creatures” addition seem to be completely unnecessary, and only serve to make 100%ing this game feel more like a chore. Also, Online Multiplayer would had really helped when it came to modes like Kung Foot, because I can’t really get my friends together all the time to play it.Presentation-Wise, Rayman Legends nails it. While I like the more zany look of Rayman Origins, Legends polishes up the artstyle to look completely unique and beautiful. When certain enemies or objects are shown as a 3D model, it doesn’t look odd or unusual, making it a solid blend of 2D and 3D visuals. It’s music is a joy to listen to, despite being dangerously close to being generic medieval fare. The UI mostly doesn’t distract the player, although the constant in-game notifications definitely are annoying.So how’s the PC version of the game? Surprisingly good! I managed to get it running 60fps on my laptop (which seems to like running games at terrible framerates), and it’s been doing superb for me on my main PC (to no surprise). If you have a low-end computer, you should give it a shot, it isn’t as intensive as it looks.Unfortunately, the game requires uPlay (which is weird because Rayman Origins didn’t!), and it’s as big of a mess as always.TL;DR - Rayman Legends is a fantastic platformer with splendid controls, tons of bonuses, and a stellar presentation. It’s still my GOTY of 2014! For more reviews on all sorts of games, follow  Lots' o Giveaway's group curations and reviews  here!Be sure to check out the rest of my reviews for LOG on OpenCritic @ http://opencritic.com/outlet/380/lots-o-giveaways

												I can't belive that i didnt picked this game earlier up.One of my steam friend bought it for me, i can't thank him enough.I'm now currently at World 4-2. So far everything that i saw was absolutly fun, cool and i could play these levels over and over, just because they are so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ awesome.One thing that this game makes it so cool is the fact of the humorous and jokes this game has to offer. Want to play as a duck? Wanna see a random giant wrestling guy falling from top to bottom just you can go on? Or do you just want to hear a plant singing by slapping his eye?Then this game should give you a good laugh.Gameplay: Nothing here changed since Origins, which i also played too (Wiii Version). I feel like Legends is easier then Origins. I had my problems getting progress in the previous game, probably because i was back there a child which had nothing better to do. Also, the levels from Legends are in my option better, but it's also cool to see that you can play the previous levels from Origins, i really like that.Bosses that i had to beat were top. My favourite one HAS to be the 3rd boss.The biggest feature are the music levels. Diffirent covers from songs, like from Black Mary, Eye of the Tiger and so on. I NEVER had so much fun playing these Music Levels. They are completly new and fresh also. if some DLC's were avalible, i would defendly try them out. Also Castle Rack has to be the best one.Soundtracks: Some soundtrack from Origins were re-used, but that doesnt matter. The soundtrack is often outstanding, is fitting really good in the currently situation you are in. I was imaging i were in a mission impossible in World 4-1, damn that was perfectly. Challenge: I never had the experience yet to be in a trial and error section. Otherwise, the game isnt too easy, and isnt too hard.  Mixing the difficulty perfect together makes an awesome game experience.Overall, this game is it money worth. Buy it now if you can!  Trust me! You will never have more fun then playing this!10/10

content:
Posted: March 29, 2015
												I have to say, this is a pretty inspired platformer. The controls are simple, power-ups are few, but instead you get treated to some seriously well designed environments. The daily and weekly challenges are a testament to how much gameplay variety the game has. There are enough background touches that replaying a level a few times, you'll notice things that you missed the first time through. The musical stages are a treat for the eyes, and a nice homage to the early auto-play ROM hacks (i.e. SMW Kumikyoku) which would do the same thing. (though you need to jump and fire to the beat, of course)You don't have a lives counter. When you die, you just start back at some arbitrary checkpoint. You can also just opt to restart at the last checkpoint via the pause menu if you messed up getting some collectible. (lums or teensies) Challenge purists may scoff at this feature but anti-frustration features such as these are long overdue. Some players go for utter perfection and they can still impose that challenge on themselves. Those of us who'd rather not endure dozens of repeats of an entire stage for one difficult section will have things the way they are. Not to mention, anti-frustration features are much more kid friendly. Finally, Ubisoft cycles through challenges every day where you can compete with the world. They have you covered, though they admittedly do a miserable job at managing the hackers.The game is fairly non-linear, with paths opening up as you collect more teensies and lucky tickets.  Teensies make more standard stages available, and tickets (eventually) open up more of the "Back to Origins" stages.90% of what I _didn't_ like about this game can be summed up in one word: UPlay. The fact that they're using steam as a conduit to push their redundant DRM system which significantly adds to the startup time is appalling. One thing you better not do is check the box that says "don't tell me again" when you close the window with your key. You won't have the steam overlay available to get it again when it's time to enter the key again, many minutes later. I almost botched my install this way...luckily I hadn't copied something else into my clipboard. This experience alone almost caused me to knee-jerk a negative review in...lucky for them, the game is extremely good.The rest of what I found irritating were some of the pop-ups after a level. One made it look like an option but literally forced me to stop what I was doing and go play an invasion level. I also kept getting annoying popups to use the tickets even though I'd already responded to one such popup. It's my own damn prerogative if I want to use them all at once. I also don't like the fact that unlocking levels is somewhat RNG based, but I'm guessing that they had the sense to heavily influence the "randomness" of unlocking said levels.All in all, I guess I recommend it. Hopefully someday Ubisoft will realize they're alienating gamers with their DRM, and...yeah, I'm sticking with Steam. Thanks. That said, the game itself is worth the annoyance.

content:
Posted: March 16, 2015
												Rayman Legends, a game that was supposed to be Wii U exclusive on February 21, 2013 and Ubisoft decides at the last second to make it multi-platforms so it was moved to September 2013. I honestly have played all the versions of this game but i only own the Wii U and PC version. Rayman Legends is a sequel to Rayman Origins where this time, instead of saving happy faces, you save the usual Teensies like in most Rayman games. There are multiple characters to play as even though there all the same. Gameplay is good however, when your playing Murphy levels, you cannot tap whatever you want unlike the Wii U version. This is frustrating since you cannot get some extra lums for a gold trophy. Every level has 2 objectives, get a certain amount of lums and save teensies. You cannot progress furthur until u get the right amunt of teensies. There are other modes in this game like Kung Foot where its basically soccer. There are also Challenges in which you do a certain objective everyday. There are 4 types of challenges: Daily.Daily Extreme,Weekly, and Weekly Extreme. The maps also change once its been a day/week and a diffrent objective like how far can you go or how fast can you get a certain amount of lums. You do get trophies for this which raises your Awesomeness level. Your Awesomess Level increases as you collect trophies as they give you points. Once you reach a certain amount of Aweomess, you unlocked all the challenges. There is also a lottery and to get tickets, you need to get a certain amount of lums in levels.I give this game 7 out of 10 because this game is literally meant for the Wii U, Plus the Wii U version has more content than the other versions like being able to control Murphy which is really good.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 17, 2015
If you're the one for nostalgic games, including Rayman, then this is the one for you! The gameplay is superb, and although it does lag a tiny bit now and then, you won't even care because you're too focused on how fun this game is. ;) Some levels require fast thinking, multi-tasking and being quick on your feet (Rayman feet) as you jump through obstacles and fight off enemies that come in your way whilst a fire blaze is coming after you. There are also lever-related levels where you have a handy sidekick guy who helps make your obstacles a bit easier, as long as you remember to use this little sidekick guy by pressing 'w', or 'q' and 'e' to make him rotate the wheel/s. Furthermore, there are mini games such as challenges, and a sports ball-kicking multi-player mini game. Throughout the game, you'll have little bonuses popping up here and there to help you gain more points/life, and during the game loads, there may be a free life-line heart which you must grab before the loading has finished (if you want to!). You also must try to free all of the little blue guys (in some or all levels) in order to gain all three trophies for each game room. Overall, from a Rayman lover, I think this game is worth the buy, especially since I was able to get it 75% off (special sale). You won't regret it, and like I similarly said, you will have so much fun once you get into the grip of the game.

												Here I was thinking Origins would be the best platformer I ever played... I am so happy I was wrong.Featuring a beautiful and lively hand-drawn world of wonder and expansive variety, your eyes will thank you for all of the stunning visuals this game has to offer. The levels feature plenty of challenge, abilites and indeed the famed music levels that will make you want to scream in exitement with every perfectly synced note.  Speaking of notes, you'll be hearing a lot of them from the same composer that wrote Origins' music... which means yet more astonishing scores to be experienced on just the soundtrack, since Cellos played as bass guitars are BADASS (look up "Dive another day" or "Lost in the Clouds").  Even after you reach 100% completion there are still new daily and weekly challenges to keep you coming back for more.You'd have to be out of your mind to think you can get a better platforming experience on PC anywhere else right now, it's an absolute no-brainer.*NOTE: THIS DOES REQUIRE UPLAY, WHICH SUCKS BUT WHATEVER*

content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
												This is the best platformer I have played in many years.   The art style and overall ambiance enhance the game experience instead of hindering it, the music perfectly matches the levels (especially the musical themed levels), and the controls are very tight.  There are so many levels to play and they are the perfect length, not too long or too short, with checkpoints on each screen transition, making some of the harder levels fun to master, instead of dreadful.  Once you beat certain levels and reach a certain level of collectibles, levels unlock that are tougher than the main campaign for those seeking challenge (they usually have time limits which require perfect control or else you will not reach the goal).  The steam version also has the previous game (Rayman Origins) included, but require unlocks to play.    For those who love platformers, this is a must-have game.

												Super fun platformer! The gameplay, the art, the soundtrack ... is all so well done. It truly makes you want to come back to the game for more hilarious fun. number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 16, 2015
												The great:  Originality seeps from every pore of this game.  The artwork is phenominal, the level design is smart, and the music is lively and joyous.  Every character is quirky and fun, even if they're not that different gameplay-wise.  Rayman Legends capitalizes on the simplicity of the platforming genre, and does it in an accessible, streamlined experience.The good:  The game modes.  When you finally exhaust the immense amount of levels, there is still more to do.  You can play a surprisingly intense round of Kung Foot, which is soccer meets the Matrix.  You can play some levels from the previous games.  You can also do some challenges that are devilishly tricky.  Obviously, this stuff was added as an afterhtought, and it isn't as fleshed out as the main levels, but it was a smart afterthought, because it is still quite fun.The bad:  It's an Ubisoft game for PC, so you know what that means.  Yup, you're gonna have to deal with the annoyance of Uplay.  Booting up the game from Steam only to have it open Uplay and update itself, and then slowly clunk you into what you actually wanted to do in the first place, which is play the game.  It's unfortunate that this exists, because the developers had nothing to do with this decision and it's all Ubisoft's fault.  Bah humbug.Overall, this is a must own for lovers of local co-op and/or platformers.  It has a unique charm about it that is unseen elsewhere, and it's worth dealing with Ubisoft's incompetence to get to the reward of this phenominal experience.Verdict:  Buy it for any price, you won't be sorry.

content:
Posted: November 18, 2013
												When you pop in this game, the first thing you notice is the poor edging on Rayman, the main character of the movie and the main character you control in the game. The Rayman Legends movie was done with Silicon Graphics Computers™ and the instruction booklet says the game's graphics were created with the same 3D computer models used in the making of the blockbuster movie.We don't know however if the game uses Silicon Graphics Computers™. If SGI Computers™ were used, we suspect they were only used for character animations because the backgrounds do not have the detailed quality graphics of Donkey Kong Country. As any good dedicated game-player knows, Donkey Kong Country was created with Silicon Graphics Computers™ and doesn't have edging problems.  Whats even more strange is that  Rayman is the only character with edging problems. All of the other characters look great.One question remains, why didn't Ubisoft use Silicon Graphics Computers™ for the entire game? Were they too expensive? I don't think so. Come on. Big Ubisoft is one of the richest corporations in France. Let's get real here.Bottom line, Barbara is cute.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												Rayman Legends is a thing of beauty!If you ever enjoyed 2D platform gaming like Super Mario Bros, or Donkey Kong Country you simply can't go wrong with this game. I would even go so far as to say this game is better.The controls are very fluid and soon become second nature. Which is just as well because after a few easy introductionary levels the difficulty picks up. It's all very nicely balanced, though. Levels that may seem impossible at first become feasible and you'll find yourself zipping through them. The feeling of satisfaction when you're conquering another world is a joy.The tunes are memorable. You'll find yourself humming them. The graphics are poetry in motion. Check the trailer and you'll see what I mean. If there's any drawback to this game (I have well over 200 hours playtime in this and my kids (4 and 6) about 50 hours between them) it's the lack of a coherent story. But really, who needs a story to a game like this? Princess Toadstool has been kidnapped by Bowser time and time again without any formal complaint. If you're into platformers, grab this game! You won't be disappointed.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2016
												This game amazed me on levels few other recent games have. For one, the game started at my fullscreen resolution without needing to be told, then I come to find out it supports a TON of screen sizes and even has windowed mode. By this point, I'm already wowed, but then I look to the left of those options, and what's this? Proper control mapping? And it recognized a gamepad other than the 360 controller? More than that, even while using a 360 controller, I can remap all the buttons! Just when I think, "Wow this is all great, could it get any better?" I absentmindedly alt+tab out to check something, and to my surprise it DOESN'T crash the game or make it have a fit, I can open it right back up no worse for wear! Someone, somewhere loved this game enough to give it a PC port with all the trimmings one deserves, and this is from Ubisoft, a company I never expect anything from.Oh yeah and it's a pretty great game too, it's got... running and jumping and stuffs. I like it.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2013
												This game is the sequel of Rayman Origins and the fifth canon game of the franchise. Superior to Origins in everything, it features lots of improvements since graphics until its gameplay. It is officially the biggest Rayman game ever, with more than 20 hours of gameplay plus the online challenges that extend more the experience.. Although it isn't better than the first three games of the quintology, this title is superior to Rayman Origins and it brings back fourty levels from it with adapted gameplay mechanics and slightly improved graphism, but the return of the RO levels might make the experience feel repetitive. Sadly, the story isn't quite improved either, it is a game that mostly focuses in gameplay. Despite of this said problems and other particular ones, it is still an enjoyable game and recommended especially to people that still didn't have the chance to play Rayman Origins. Recommended.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												While 2D platformers struggle to stay relevant in the current AAA market, Rayman Legends was my personal GOTY of 2013. Building off from Rayman Origins, Legends ups the scale with more variation and scale while maintaining the natural flow and personality of before. Although the original campaign is of a fair length and difficulty (though slightly lower than Origins' hair-pulling time trials), it'll give a good reason to check back every day for new content.If you can't afford a WiiU, the PC version is a very acceptable option for the solo player. Runs smoothly and looks great.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Great game if you like classic 2D-ish platformers. It has very beutiful levels with colorful artwork, bonus levels in the form of music levels, speed run levels (like in Rayman Jungle Run) after a certain point for every level in the game, Dark Rayman speed run levels, challenge levels where you play against other players, local co-op, leaderboards and a whole LOT of polish and light puzzles. Very satisfying to play.The game also features remastered Rayman Origins (previous title) levels, and you can play as a lot more then rayman (4 characters with a ton of variations between them).

												Out of all the Rayman games I've played I got to say I enjoyed this one the most. I still think Rayman 2 is generally a better overall game due to it's nice story and atmosphere, but this game is just so satisfying to play. Everything from the gameplay, tight controls, co-op, music, stage-variety, bosses, design, daily/weekly challenges and even the Origins levels are just amazing. number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 10, 2016
												I bought this game a long time ago. Before I started writing these reviews nobody reads. Today I decided to reinstall this game  because I needed some inspiration, as I make games on my spare time and I remembered this game as one of the most amazing looking games I ever played, then write a review nobody will read. Every screenshot is an artwork. But visuals anyone can tell how good it is by looking at the videos and screenshots, so I'll move on and talk about the rest of the game. By the way, if you're into art I also recommend googling Rayman concept art and get to know Aymeric Kevin's artwork, the artist behind it.Now that I started writing this I realize I don't have much to say about the game. There is nothing new to be analyzed; you jump and attack through the levels. So I'll put it like this: imagine the best 2D platformer you ever played, it's likely done by a small team, indie. Now imagine if that game had the amount of polish a triple A game  usually gets. That's Rayman Legends. Every second on it seems to have been crafted by a hundred skilled hands and playtested to exhaustion. It's so well paced that at times it's challenging without being frustrating, at other times it's easy without being boring. At the end of each chapter there's a musical level where you run and jump as you do in bit runner and other rhythm running games, and it's so fun I was laughing out loud while playing. Laughing because you are having fun is not something I'm used to. Laughing of a good joke? sure, but it's not the same thing. It's a super nice variation from the previous levels and it does feel like a reward for beating every level. This is something we always want as gamers, rewards for beating the game. It's why we watch the whole credits and absorb every bit of extra content we have. In the old days we would examine every pixel of those static images of the end game credits. I feel like These musical at the end of each chapter gives us exactly what we want. An explosive and fun reward for all the "work".Also, it's not every day you see a reboot light years better than the source material. It baffles me every time I remember what the original rayman was like.If that's not obvious by now, I quite like Rayman Legends and I recommend it.

Posted: October 7, 2014
												Mario ain't got nothing on Rayman Legends. Slamming music, tight controls, eye-bleedingly astounding art direction, 4 player-same-screen-co-op on PC. Show up for the charm and amazing aesthetics. Stay for the super-hard-core platforming action. RESCUE ALL THE TEENSIES!Hands down one of the most finely crafted platformers I've ever come across. You owe it to yourself to check out Rayman Legends. Just make sure to rebind Murphy's context button. It's horribly placed. =DHowever, there's a pretty big asterisk to this review: Like most Ubisoft games, this game requres you to maintain a Ubisoft Uplay account in order to run the game. I don't care, personally, but a lot of people are turned off by draconian DRM measures that Ubi has put in place. Making matters even more confusing, Ubi is evolving Uplay into its own digital distribution platform ala Steam. So it's like Steam-ception. It's a Steam within a Steam, albiet a Steam that is geared towards Ubi's publisher proclivities. So, to recap, you have to download a digitial distribution service through your digital distribution service in order to play the game. Like I said, doesn't bother me, but I know it sure as hell bothers a lot of people.

content:
Posted: April 17, 2014
												This is the best platformer I have ever played. Take everything great about Rayman Origins and make it even better. All the great stage design, boss fights, and challenging difficulty is back. There is so much content in this installment of the Rayman series. Online challenges, remastered Rayman Origins stages, Local Co-Op mode with a fun minigame, Time Trials, creatures to collect, characters to unlock and a ton of awesomely designed stages in the main section of the game. There is also a nice statistics screen to keep track of all your progress.There are online challenges that change on a daily and weekly basis. Every player in the world competes in them and gets ranked by how well they perform in the challenge. You can also race against the better ranked player's ghosts. It basically shows exactly what they did during the challenge, while you are playing. You can also increase your trophy level by placing high in lots of challenges and clearing portions of the game. The music themed stages in this game are probably my favorite platforming levels in any game ever. Playing a whole level in sync with the music feels very satisfying. There are also a ton of other stages that are amazingly designed. The boss fights are very satisifying to play. The Time Trials portions of stages feel perfectly designed for running through them as fast as you can. There is quite a bit of depth in making your character move as fast as possible in all situations. These Time Trials make you realize how fast you can actually go.I have spent around 40 hours to 100% the game and do some of the online challenges. You can probably spend around 30 hours just to 100% the game and around 20 hours trying to complete the levels. Some of the levels are very hard and the online challenges have sections that are even harder. They bring back portions of the Land of the Livid Dead from Rayman Origins for some of the online challenges. You can also play a lot of the Rayman Origins levels in this game, but they have been remastered to make the levels a bit better designed. This game has everything you could want in a platformer. It is highly recommended and I don't think you can find a better designed platformer game than this one. Go buy it now!

content:
Posted: February 28, 2015
												Context:Well polished and rich game, reminds me of the rich, unique, original and well polished work that used to come out more often in the past, caring so much about the finer details that make a game a universe of its own. Considering how the CoD and AC series were initially at a such high level of quality, especially the first releases but later declined with every sequel. It is therefore a surprise how Ubisoft with its overall declining quality, managed to produce such a great quality work with this one. Could this mean the same for its other series? Only time will tell, since as Ubisoft has shown here, it's never too late to get back on track.Some snippets from the game itself: +This game as many others have mentioned, is suitable for all ages and is great for gathering friends and family in playing such a fun game cooperatively or competitively.+Every level is unique on its own, giving a different flow, challenges and experience to every level, this is one of the major factors that make the game so replayable.+Small details regarding playable and non-playable characters in their movements and reactions to the envirnoment, which are so well made that not only do they truly give an impression of the personality of the character, but aids in making the gameplay experience so fluid.+Manages to instill an actual sense of achievement, versus a ton of modern games that reward 'achievements' without the actual senseMinor negatives:-Requires Uplay which constantly and forever will have sync issues with achievements or saved games. (I never needed to backup saves for Rayman, but for AC:Unity and Sleeping Dogs, which overwrote my progress, I needed to backup my saves constantly mid-game)-Only local Coop +Counter: However this encourages getting actual persons to play with you in the same room, which enriches the experience. Also, there is an online score ladder, with other player's ghosts to compete with in the weekly/daily online competitions.Rating: 9/10

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 9, 2014
												I have always been fascinated by the Rayman series because of the good graphics, but I never liked the games very much and never related in any way to the main character. However, giving this newest part of the series a chance was a very rewarding decision. The developers did nearly everything right in my opinion:gameplay - just great, you have perfect control over the character and a lot of different moves, in part depending on your environment amount of content - the game is really exemplary in this respect: multiple playable characters, a huge amount of levels and additional daily and weekly mini challenges that remodel certain areas difficulty - even though challenging at times, the game always seems to be fair and does not lead to a lot of frustration (and I played all the locked and hidden levels)design - the graphics are beautiful, especially the vegetation and the sci-fi stuff. the level design is very good and keeps you entertained with varying design elements and a lot of funny and crazy ideassound - the sound effects and most of the music is great and original, sometimes very atmospheric, more often very funny. some of the tracks could have been better suited to underline the atmosphere of certain areas. the music-themed levels (in which your movements have to be in line with the music) are awesome in general, as is the music for the underwater levels  In sum, I can really recommend this game to everyone who likes to play platformers. Even If you only like some of the platformer classics, but stopped playing that type of game for a long time - you probably should give this game a try :)[fanboy mode off]

content:
Posted: March 6, 2015
												This game is pretty great. If you liked Rayman:Origins, you'll like this one. If you don't have Origins, you don't really need to buy it, since this game contains almost every one of the origins levels as bonus levels. It's a great idea, and they're fun to revisit. If you like fun, cheerful platformers with good music, good controls, and a good difficulty curve, you'll really like this game. However, unless you really enjoy pain, I'd recommend finishing the main levels and quitting. By the time I realized that was what I should have done, I was close enough to 100% that I just soldiered through, but it really left a sour taste in my mouth in places. One of the best parts of Rayman:Origins for me was how the difficulty ramped up through the whole game, culminating in the Land of the Livid Dead. Those levels were monsters, but practice and a bit of luck would see you through, and man did I feel accomplished when I beat them. You needed every single trick you'd picked up in the game, and maybe a few more, but they weren't unfair, just brutal. Rayman:Legends on the other hand, has a land of the livid dead that's not new, it's not interesting, it's just selected levels you've already beaten with hideous graphical filters over them. Pixelating them, adding pulsing static and other visual noise, oh, and removing the checkpoints. Two of them gave me hideous headaches. Just for that alone, I'd have to say Origins is the stronger game. Legends also adds a whole bunch of timed mini levels, some of which can take dozens of runs if you're trying to rescue all of the smurfs that have been captured. Some of them are a nice break, but having so many of them makes the magic run dry very quickly. I'd also like to know why there are ~40 unlockable playable characters when there aren't appreciable differences between them. Not sure what the point there is. Anyway, overall, this game is in places good, even great, but for completests, it's a bit of a kick below the belt in the places it should really shine. I recommend it, but with the caveats mentioned.

Posted: December 3, 2013
												Amazing game. I've loved the Rayman series for it's immersive gameplay and unique style since the announcement of Rayman Origins. Ubiart Framework is a fantastic studio and I just adore this game like no other. The game is quirky and fun, you'll notidce that little is serious about this game when you play it. It's comical and charming all together. Fans of Rayman Origins will definitely enjoy this game. It has a lot more features than Rayman Origins had-In this game you collect Teensies, there're 10 in each level, and how many in each painting varies. In the invasion levels, and other specific levels(such as bosses or music levels) there're 3 teensies to collect. Each level is just an epic immersion into the marvels Ubiart Framework can achieve with their technology. The music is phenominal, it adds dynamic to the overall gameplay and allows the player to truly get into the game, and the E3 press conference mostly emphasized one of the music levels-but it's not just the music levels that have great music. The entire game has a beautiful soundtrack that truly adds to the game's feeling. I only have a few complaints about the game...Some of the invasion levels are merciless and tedious. For one level I spent a good hour trying to get it just right to earn all 3 teensies. The levels are put together awesomely, but the spike in difficulty of invasion levels sometimes takes a toll on gameplay. If you're a perfectionist, it becomes more of a chore than something fun...But it feels great once you do get it just right. The daily and weekly challenges always add a spice to the game, allowing for players to earn more lums for completing various tasks in certain levels, it helps keep things fresh, and it definitely made me come back for more because I always wonder what's going to be the challenge for today. In this game you recieve lottery tickets after earning so many Lums, which is pretty cool-but you can also earn 'creatures' for your creature gallery. I never really understood the creature collection. They supply lums daily, but otherwise they don't seem very collectible unless you just, you know, like to collect them(personal opinion). Overall this game is amazing. It's worth every penny,

Posted: April 26, 2014
												Obligatory header to the review: I focus on four primary areas whenever I review a game: gameplay, story, graphics, and sound/audio/general things that go into your earholes. Gameplay and Story get a rating scale from 1 to 10, and the AV stuff gets a rating from 1 to 5. My philosophy on this is that there are some instances in which a game may not necessarily have that much in the way of gameplay (take Amnesia for example), but the story/atmosphere/whatever it may be is reason enough to pick it up. Also, take the cumulative score with a grain of salt; it's just a numerical feeling about the game as a whole. That's part of why I do these subscores. Also, keep in mind that I'm not going off of school grade based rankings. A 5/10 denotes what I feel to be an average game. Likewise, 7/10 is a game that I think is pretty cool, and something that gets a 2/10 is near-abomination level. Pinning scores to an even further obfuscated rating scale is kinda senseless, but for the sake of my backloggery, I'll repeat again that 1.0-2.7 is a one-star game, 3.0-4.7 is a two-star game, 5.0-6.7, 7.0-8.7, and 9.0-10 are three, four, and five stars, respectively.Gameplay: Rayman Origins was a very fun and generally very well designed game, if slightly flawed in certain areas. Rayman Legends is a very fun and generally very well designed game, if slightly flawed in certain areas. It's the same "old-school" platforming experience delivered in Rayman Origins, but this time it's delivered just a bit better. Gone are some of the absolutely infuriating and sometimes unfair memorization-heavy levels (for the most part; I'll get to that later). Out of the core five worlds, there were really only three levels that I wasn't too terribly fond of. For a game that has about 40 levels in the core worlds, that's quite good. In fact, my only "minor-major" complaint about the core worlds is the implementation of Murphy. It shows that he was meant for the Wii U version, but it's not that much of a deal breaker; just that it maybe could've been handled in a slightly better manner (let's say controlling Murphy with the right analog stick). Note that I signified the fact that the ratio of good to bad levels was quite good in the core worlds. There is also a portion of the game called "Back to Origins," which is essentially a best-of collection of levels from Rayman Origins. Again, most of these levels are pretty good, but it just seems lazy to me to only bring back some of the levels, rather than bring back all of them. They've essentially given us all of the good stuff, leaving us no reason to go out and buy Origins. Much to my annoyance, they also brought back the boss fights from Origins, which are the aforementioned unfair memorization-heavy levels. They were the worst part of Origins in my opinion, but they are not the worst part in this game.That "honor" goes to the Livid Dead Party world, which in my opinion contains some of the worst levels in the game. The Land of the Livid Dead level from Origins was easily my favorite level in the entire game, so you can imagine my disappointment when I found that all that was new and Livid Dead related was another music stage. It wasn't bad, but it was still very disappointing. Then... the remixes strike. These are 8-Bit reprises of the music stages that you unlock at the end of each world, with the two primary differences being a lack of checkpoints and an (in my opinion) incredibly stupid and infuriating visual filter(s). The first stage wasn't so bad; it just kinda hurt my head since it was a fisheye lens. The second stage... made me not want to 100% the game, even though I had gotten 682 Teensies up to that level. I don't get motion sickness, but that stage nearly made me throw up about three times due to the godawful visual filter done exclusively for "LAWLZ RETRO GUIZ." The rest of the stages were more of the same, albeit not nearly as bad as the second remix stage.Again, despite my negativity, I will wholeheartedly recommend this game to anyone who anyone who just wants a pure fun platforming experience. Just stick with 100%ing the core worlds; the rest of the game ain't worth it. For an incredibly well crafted and fun set of core levels, a mediocre way of padding out the gameplay, and an immensely disappointing Livid Dead world, I will give this game an 8.5/10 for gameplay.Story: Skipping this, as the story can literally be told in less than a paragraph.Graphics: Man, I wish Ubisoft would release the level creator/editing tool to the public so that we can do things with it. Then again, maybe it's for the best that they don't; it'd only be a matter of time until the Internet poops all over such a glorious utility. What I'm trying to say is that this game is gorgeous and that we (as consumers) should totally be able to get our hands on the editor to make more amazing stuff happen. The character design is quite good as well, if some of the characters start to look like the others after a while. Despite this, there's a great deal of characters that you can switch between, so that you're not stuck staring at the same character the entire game. For proving yet again that style trumps number of polygons, this game gets a 5/5 for graphics.Music: You can tell that the composers had a great deal of fun with the music in this game. That fun of composing transcribes into additional fun in playing the game. It's not something that most people would want to listen to outside of the game (at least I'd think so), but it's still very fitting and lends itself quite nicely to the ambiance of the stages. The songs chosen for the music stages puts this soundtrack over the top, allowing it to receive a 5/5 for the music portion.Overall score of 8.5/0/5/5; cumulative score of 9.3/10. If I didn't decide to be a completionist for this game, I would've rated it higher; however, the Livid Dead Party is still a pretty large blemish on an otherwise excellent game. Again, the best experience is achieved by just sticking to the core five worlds in my opinion.

Posted: January 12, 2014
												I'm writing this review at about 50% complettion of the game, so keep that in mind. Having played the Rayman Origins game with a friend, I knew what I was getting into. That being said, this is probably the best implemented local coop game I've played in years. They managed to take Rayman Origins and remove most of the annoying things (poorly implemented levels for multiple players, confusing map, etc.), and added a ton of new imaginative content that just blows you away. Seriously, the first time we got to the final level for one of the "stories" we were just blown away by how amazing the game we were playing was. I don't want to spoil it, but I can say that if you get this game and get some friends together to play with a few Xbox controllers, you'll have a fantastic time.

Posted: April 20, 2014
												Rayman Legends is a must have if you; enjoy sidscrolling platformers, played Rayman Origins and liked it or you are a fan of the Rayman franchise.First of all, the art style is outstanding! I was amazed after playing Origins as it just looks beautiful. Everything is very unique and have very smooth animations with each boss being 3D but looking like they are still 2D.Secondly, the sounds and music are amazing with comedic sound effects for hitting enemies and great music that suites each atmosphere very well.The level design is very well done with many challenging and gorgeous looking levels you won't get bored, with levels filled with secrets normally hard to get to, intense boss battles, fast paced music based levels and difficult time trials. There is also a extra area containing levels from Rayman Origins with the new art style and new lum system.The game also supports controllers and allows up to 4 players locally, unfortunately like Origins there is no online co-op support, although it does have a daily and weekly challenge which has online leaderboards and gives you prizes depending on how high you were in the leaderboards.The length of the game is hard to say but as you can see I have played quite a bit of it and still have not got everything with there being 700 teensies to collect and the addicting challenges you will pump hours into this game, if you do have people to play locally with then there is a game mode called 'Kung Foot' which is a football game where you have a very small area to play with 2 teams. The ball is very bouncy and can be hit all over the place making it very chaotic and fun. Although there is a lot to do once you do it all and collect everything you most likely won't play it an awful lot after although you may replay after a year or so or if you have a friend to play it with again.Some improvements from Origins stand out other than the extended gameplay and improved art style which is that they removed the annoying thing where enemies turned into bubbles on death, although the player bubble death is there which isn't a bad thing. The lums have also been improved making it so the first lum in a row of lums is purple/pink and if collected will give 2 lums and will pass onto the next lum unless a yellow one is collected making collecting the lums in order more important and can be challenging when they moving around. The amount of collectables has also been increased.Lastly, the characters in the game are similar to the ones in Origins just with a few more reskins but also the addition of the princess-barbarians which wield an axe as a weapon the first one being Barbara which each need to be rescued. Although there are many characters the reskins are very minor for the princesses mainly.Overall I highly recommend buying this game it is certainly worth it full price, one problem people may have is that it is run through uPlay which means you need to make a uPlay account as well and can sometimes be a problem for people. I was very pleased with pre-ordering this game for £25 which also got me Rayman Origins free with it.

Posted: September 3, 2013
												You don't know Rayman until you play Origins, you REALLY don't know Rayman until you play Legends. Rayman returns to kick a lot of butt in this game. So many levels to play, characters to unlock, activities to play, and bosses to fight. Since this game has Uplay, you are able to play with other Uplay people and friends who have a Uplay account in Multi-player battles and challenges. Leaderboard and all, not only do you play the levels, but they have daily and weekly challenges for you to play. Seriously this will keep me busy for months. You don't know the Legends until you PLAY the Legends!

Posted: November 17, 2013
												A superb platformer. It packs a lot more "stuff" compared to Origins, not to mention Origins is pretty much in the game from unlocks. The difficulty lies somwhere between old school and new school, but the later unlockable levels and "invaison levels" will be a severe challenge. Overall a fantastic game.

Posted: January 3, 2014
												If you like torture and pain, if you like failing tens and hundreds of times in a row, if you like dying whenever anything touches you, if you like repeating the same area over and over again until getting the perfect score, this is the game for you. It contains so many challenges that it's hard to count them all.Lack of Steam achievements (well, at least Uplay achievements work) and online co-op and cloud saves, extremely slow startup of Uplay, no instructions on advanced moves, issues with servers* and other drawbacks are annoying, but I can bear with it because it's one of the best platformers ever. Before the resurrection of Rayman, AAA platformers were dead and the genre was left to indies. I'm immensely delighted that I can play Rayman now and small annoyances won't stop me.The game contains levels from Rayman Origins, but you should still buy the previous game because the gameplay has been serously changed. Graphics have been upgraded, but new remixes are not as balanced and perfected as the original levels.P.S. Music levels are AWESOME.* Server and connection issues may vary depending on your location. There are also some bugs with country/server detection.

Again, most of these levels are pretty good, but it just seems lazy to me to only bring back some of the levels, rather than bring back all of them. They've essentially given us all of the good stuff, leaving us no reason to go out and buy Origins. Much to my annoyance, they also brought back the boss fights from Origins, which are the aforementioned unfair memorization-heavy levels. They were the worst part of Origins in my opinion, but they are not the worst part in this game.That "honor" goes to the Livid Dead Party world, which in my opinion contains some of the worst levels in the game. The Land of the Livid Dead level from Origins was easily my favorite level in the entire game, so you can imagine my disappointment when I found that all that was new and Livid Dead related was another music stage. It wasn't bad, but it was still very disappointing. Then... the remixes strike. These are 8-Bit reprises of the music stages that you unlock at the end of each world, with the two primary differences being a lack of checkpoints and an (in my opinion) incredibly stupid and infuriating visual filter(s). The first stage wasn't so bad; it just kinda hurt my head since it was a fisheye lens. The second stage... made me not want to 100% the game, even though I had gotten 682 Teensies up to that level. I don't get motion sickness, but that stage nearly made me throw up about three times due to the godawful visual filter done exclusively for "LAWLZ RETRO GUIZ." The rest of the stages were more of the same, albeit not nearly as bad as the second remix stage.Again, despite my negativity, I will wholeheartedly recommend this game to anyone who anyone who just wants a pure fun platforming experience. Just stick with 100%ing the core worlds; the rest of the game ain't worth it. For an incredibly well crafted and fun set of core levels, a mediocre way of padding out the gameplay, and an immensely disappointing Livid Dead world, I will give this game an 8.5/10 for gameplay.Story: Skipping this, as the story can literally be told in less than a paragraph.Graphics: Man, I wish Ubisoft would release the level creator/editing tool to the public so that we can do things with it. Then again, maybe it's for the best that they don't; it'd only be a matter of time until the Internet poops all over such a glorious utility. What I'm trying to say is that this game is gorgeous and that we (as consumers) should totally be able to get our hands on the editor to make more amazing stuff happen. The character design is quite good as well, if some of the characters start to look like the others after a while. Despite this, there's a great deal of characters that you can switch between, so that you're not stuck staring at the same character the entire game. For proving yet again that style trumps number of polygons, this game gets a 5/5 for graphics.Music: You can tell that the composers had a great deal of fun with the music in this game. That fun of composing transcribes into additional fun in playing the game. It's not something that most people would want to listen to outside of the game (at least I'd think so), but it's still very fitting and lends itself quite nicely to the ambiance of the stages. The songs chosen for the music stages puts this soundtrack over the top, allowing it to receive a 5/5 for the music portion.Overall score of 8.5/0/5/5; cumulative score of 9.3/10. If I didn't decide to be a completionist for this game, I would've rated it higher; however, the Livid Dead Party is still a pretty large blemish on an otherwise excellent game. Again, the best experience is achieved by just sticking to the core five worlds in my opinion.
