Posted: April 11, 2016
												Rayman Legends definitely lives up to the old style of Rayman games, with a little more extra features than the older games.It features over 120 different stages each with varying atmosphere, amazing music, and plenty of hidden collectibles. Each of the levels are hand drawn and beautiful to look at. Despite not being overly impressive on a technical level, Rayman uses a timeless style. While games like Crysis 3 probably won’t look that great 10 years from now, Rayman Legends will no doubt retain its charm.There are underwater stealth missions, time trials, and even musical stages where you jump to the rhythm of remixed popular songs that'll have you laughing stupidly hard at how at first you won't understand what's going on but quickly have a hard time playing because of the nostalgia that hits you as you go further into the stage. The inclusion of daily and weekly challenges allows you to compete with your friends, adding tons and TONS of re-playability. The weekly challenges come with leaderboards so you'll always feel accomplished having topped a certain percentile in the gaming community.The community is great, many of which have turned into speed gamers for this game.8/10

Posted: September 12, 2013
												You know, it's funny. Rayman was once considered "just another platform game" but now with Sonic running underwhelming sequels and Mario failing to do anything new or creative since Mario Galaxy, it's Rayman whose ultimately on top and destroying them with what is hands down one of the best examples of a platform game in over a decade.The first thing you'll notice about Rayman is the atmosphere. With beautiful hand-drawn artwork and polish that is truly unrivaled, the game gives off an immediate great first impression. Fortunately it doesn't stop there.Lead by great music and fantastic level design, Rayman Legends manages to snag your attention and hold on to it for dear life. Constantly changing things up, every world adds new concepts and eases them in with an old-school "learn by doing" approach.With that said, it should be said that this game can get very hard. It starts out easy but very quickly ramps things up. This is of course expected of a Rayman game and wouldn't be one without being as punishing as it is beautiful.And the best part of it all is... content. The game has a ton of it and it all holds up to the same level of quality. If you're even the slightest bit interested, you'd be a fool not to buy it. Easily my game of the year for 2013.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2016
												Rayman has always been one of my favorite series. And yep, Rayman Legends is not an exception.First, about the graphics. This game has came a long way from the previous Rayman game i've played on PC, "Rayman Origins". The graphics is STUNNING. I mean literally, it's like, the whole different game from Rayman Origins, from the world, to every character in the game, all have been enhanced, and they fit with the world perfectly. And the best part is, this game runs at full 60FPS in my crappy laptop. Yes, not a single drop, it's always stable at 60, all the time. That's the one i like most.Ok, now about the storyline. Rayman Legends, like the other Rayman games before, puts you in a funny storyline. Well gotta say, in my opinion, this game is made to make you laugh, specially when you're playing coop with your friends. Every levels is well designed, suitable for both adults and children to play together, not too hard, but also not too easy, just challenging enough. Also, this game has a "Back To Origin" part, where you can play the levels from Rayman Origins (but this doesn't mean I recommend you to play just the Legends one, i've finished Rayman Origins, and currently playing Legends, and tbh, each game has its own unique style, you can try both if you want)Thirdly, i really don't understand why people don't recommend this game because of just "Uplay". For the first 3 hours, i haven't encountered any crash, bug, or something like that. When i launch the game from steam. Uplay just pops up for a few seconds, then I'm enjoying the game, without any bug, or crash. (And for those who can't play properly because of Uplay, and want to rate down the game, here's my suggestion: After you've launched the game, saw Uplay pop-up said "logging in", shut it down, uninstall Uplay, and download the other version at Ubisoft homepage, install it. After that, you can launch the game properly)[EDIT] How could i forget about the music, the soundtrack? They are like, what made this game to become a success. All of the music, specially the music levels, are amazing, that's the part made me want to play it again and again (Still in love with the Mexican style music) xDDDIn general, i think this game is perfect to play when you want to relax, or playing with your friends and family. Seriously, i couldn't think of anything bad about this game. So yeah, my score for it is 10/10. Recommended.

Posted: March 15, 2015
												From what i've played so far, the game is really fun. Though, there are quite a few sections in the game where (assuming you're using an Xbox controller) you have to press Y to control a fairy guy to activate obsticles on the course, and it's a little obvious it was made for the WiiU's gamepad. It's a better transition then you think it would be, but it really ruins the pasing in my opinion, the flow is almost completely ruined in those levels. (Update: It's worked in a lot more levels, but in quite a few he could definitally been left out) That, and the added punishment for people who actually bought the game, and no one else, which is known as "Uplay" (A DRM service for ubisoft games as an anti-piracy method) is also used for the game. Multiple people have reported Uplay crashes when attempting to boot up the game, and they have also reported stolen gamekeys, so Uplay doesn't think you actually bought the game when you did, and the customer service is reluctant to help. So be cautious with the software. Currently, i'm unable to get cards and steam acheivements because of Uplay, so that's a bummer. Probably won't go for that completionist because of it. (just saying, Uplay is basically gunlaws for piracy, the only people you're punishing is the honest.)But, with the game's amazing art, controls, gameplay, music, and even a large collection of levels from Rayman Origins, it's definitally worth getting on sale, just in case Uplay does ♥♥♥♥ you over. Otherwise, i'd maybe even spend the 40 if you're a platformer or rayman fan. And it's easy to see that Ubiart put a lot of care into the game, they even added lore for pallet swaps. Reccomended.Edit: forgot to mention the lack of online multiplayer, because "You can't punch people over the internet."Ubi pls no.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												A sequel to one of my favorite platforming game (Rayman Origins.) Legends surpasses Origins in every single way. It looks better, it plays better, more characters, more skins, and it has more levels. You can even unlock some of the original levels from Origins to play on the new engine.You don’t see many AAA platformers released on PC anymore, and it’s a shame because Legends is just a joy to play.I love the music levels at the end of each world. It’s truly amazing when you have each step and action sync up to the song playing in the background. One of my complaints is that there is only local co-op. There is no online multiplayer available.Legends is a must play for anyone. If you’re still on the fence there is a demo to download.

												The best platformer i've ever played. It's genius from the word go.. the payoff levels at the end of the worlds are fantastic additions. Everything just screams quality and it's obvious a lot of care was put into making sure the game flows smoothly. Amazingly enough, it also has a great soundtrack to complement the action, it feels really organic and changes seamlessly to suit what's happening on the screen. As a nice bonus it even features the best levels from the previous Rayman title, itself a modern classic.This is a seriously underrated game here, the only drawback being that it may be a bit too easy with unlimited lives and no timers. That doesn't bug me at all though and there are more than enough challenges and baubles to make up for it.

												This sequel to Origins managed to surprise me even from the first level.First of all, the most noticeable thing is the flow of animation - smooth actions drawn perfectly.Second of all, its a great way to pass some time with your friends - both levels and other options such as football and daily\weekly challenges will surely draw some laughs (Plus its a great time punching your friends on the load screens).Last of all, each world ends with both a boss and a musical level - and as soon as you learn that, the anticipation to experiance more levels hits sky high.Totally recommended.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												Rayman Origins felt like a test. A well-thoughtout game, but a bit unpolished. Legends adds that extra pollish to both controls and art style, although that's hardly what feels improved. Difficulty curves quite nicely letting people experiment and mess around without being forced to progress until later on, and the controls are very responsive (even when used with a controller! Controller mappings are rebindable). The games tacked-on "underwater" world isn't actually too bad, more requiring critical thinking than it does skill and percision. Challenge support for this game isn't too unique, I've seen challenges repeated quite often although it was nice to see that I ranked at the very top of Gold-level players. Even if you aren't good at said challenges, a "ghost" option lets you hone and improve your skills and learn from other players.Although... I've two semi-obvious complaints. The Ubisoft DRM can be quite invasive before gameplay, REQUIRING updates to its service and making you lauch the game from its Uplay service (I do not approve of it, mind you). My other negative thought being there is NO online multiplayer. Enjoy crowding around your monitor with 3 other people shoving controllers into every USB port you have.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16, 2014
												So I was excited as I could've been for this to come out, seeing as how Rayman Origins was proabably my fave 2D platformer in a long while. It was on the day when this became available for preorder that I noticed it had mandatory Uplay DRM. I swore not to buy it at full price, let alone preorder it, solely because of that fact. I would not be the one supporting DRM in my DRM, no sir.I eventually bought this more than half off and found out that there's no option to disable gamepad rumble, and do believe that I loathe rumble.After having muttered some Ubisoft addressed swear words I started playing and...  I forgot about my well-founded self-rightous hate in all but a few minutes. It's slick, intuitive and responsive, the sound design is one of the best you'll ever find and the graphics are sure to make you widen up your eyes on occasion.Do I recommend getting this game? Of course I do. Do I recommend getting this game on Steam? Not necessarily.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												From what i've played so far, the game is really fun. Though, there are quite a few sections in the game where (assuming you're using an Xbox controller) you have to press Y to control a fairy guy to activate obsticles on the course, and it's a little obvious it was made for the WiiU's gamepad. It's a better transition then you think it would be, but it really ruins the pasing in my opinion, the flow is almost completely ruined in those levels. (Update: It's worked in a lot more levels, but in quite a few he could definitally been left out) That, and the added punishment for people who actually bought the game, and no one else, which is known as "Uplay" (A DRM service for ubisoft games as an anti-piracy method) is also used for the game. Multiple people have reported Uplay crashes when attempting to boot up the game, and they have also reported stolen gamekeys, so Uplay doesn't think you actually bought the game when you did, and the customer service is reluctant to help. So be cautious with the software. Currently, i'm unable to get cards and steam acheivements because of Uplay, so that's a bummer. Probably won't go for that completionist because of it. (just saying, Uplay is basically gunlaws for piracy, the only people you're punishing is the honest.)But, with the game's amazing art, controls, gameplay, music, and even a large collection of levels from Rayman Origins, it's definitally worth getting on sale, just in case Uplay does ♥♥♥♥ you over. Otherwise, i'd maybe even spend the 40 if you're a platformer or rayman fan. And it's easy to see that Ubiart put a lot of care into the game, they even added lore for pallet swaps. Reccomended.Edit: forgot to mention the lack of online multiplayer, because "You can't punch people over the internet."Ubi pls no.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2016
												Rayman has always been a fun franchise.  Legends is no exception.  Quick, fast-paced gameplay keeps you engaged while a great soundtrack provides a suitably energetic backdrop for  the polished graphics.  To clarify, what I'm talking about is, if you've ever heard the phrase "polished to a mirror finish" only they started with mirrors and polished THOSE to a mirror finish.  The graphics on this game are less graphics and more just plain art.  The game is teeming with environments and characters that are vibrant and full of humor while some rotating challenges give you reason to pick up the game even after not playing for a while.  Between the slick platforming that smartly straddles the line between fun and annoying and the zany characters, you could theoretically get a good number of hours out of this.It's a shame that none of that matters.  Rayman isn't tarnished by some small issue, it's not marred by some defect, it's truly maimed, defenestrated then lit on fire and run-over by a garbage truck named Uplay.   If you're unfamiliar with Uplay, I want you to imagine something which is both uninteresting and yet rage-inducing.  A program which is supposed to launch other programs but magically doesn't when you want it to.  Imagine something which takes up disk space, memory and wants to start at startup just like a real program but isn't useful.  A program which, and I don't want to cause you to panic, makes EA Origin look like a decent launcher.If you're having a good time imagining that, you should call Ubisoft HR because I bet they'd love to have you working for them.  Then again, if you're on Steam, you might not be "out of touch with the gaming community as a whole" which is apparently a job requirement for working there.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												I'd never played a Rayman game before and so I had absolutely no idea what to expect when I started up Rayman Legends for the first time. Man, was I ever pleasantly surprised! It's truly one of the most fun games I've ever played. While not particularly deep from a gameplay perspective, good humor is bursting from every seam and it's impossible not to be swept along.The level design is perfect and the visuals are utterly spectacular. I find myself playing "just one more level" to see what incredible visual treats the game has in store for me next. I also have to single out the game's remarkable composer, Christophe Héral. Music is as integral to the experience here as it was in classic Warner Bros. cartoons. You may find yourself replaying certain levels again and again just to enjoy the wonderful soundtrack. Of particular note is the fact that many of the tracks were recorded using a full orchestra, something which is very rare in games these days. Huge kudos to Ubisoft for being willing to spend the extra money to get such high quality results!In conclusion, Rayman Legends is pretty much a must-have game. I think gamers of all skill levels, ages and backgrounds will find plenty to enjoy here.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												This title was a complete surprise for me. I did not expect this game to win me over like it did, but its aesthetic and its polish are unbelievable. This is a must buy for any fan of platforming games. This is the culmination of decades of creating platform games, and they nailed it. -The game looks absolutely incredible. There are 3D elements tied into the 2D perspective and they really did an amazing job with it. The game is VERY colourful and looks super crisp on my monitor at 1920x1080. -The game runs like a dream, no problems there. The graphics settings are rather limited, however. -The game features precision platforming but at times it becomes a spectacle-platformer of sorts -It incorporates very creative ideas in its level design, including rhythm courses where your actions sync up with the music - this was incredible. I had a smile on my face the entire time, it is a must play, or at least a must watch on YouTube.  -The game is very deep, with tons of unlockable heroes and weekly and daily challenges, etc. Leaderboards are very prominent. The replayability of this game is unbelievable. -I HIGHLY reccomend you play this game with a controller. It is doable on keyboard with some keybinding adjustment required, but I much prefer the controller.I cannot say enough about this title! Must-own.

content:
Posted: March 18, 2016
												- This review isn't written by a native speaker, thank you for your understanding -- If you haven't found this review helpful or if you have found a mistake please leave a comment below -Rating Must PlayPlatform U PLAY (actions, rewards and achievements)- Key features below ---- Review after -----------------------------------------------Play time needed (perfect) more than 40 hoursGaming level between Casual and GamerAchievement level Gamer to Hardcore Gamer for the challengesGame style Platformer, Local Co-Op, Online challenge (daily and weekly), Shooting (mosquito), Soccer (mini-game), Farming (lums)Game modes Story mode, Time trial, Rayman Origins levels (including the mosquito shooting game), Soccer mini-game, challenges (daily and weekly) and a Online community Yes.Story Yeah, and as always : save the teensies !Playthrough 1Voice Yes, the Rayman voices.Music Yes, really good !Controls Keyboard or controllerTutorial Yes !Unmissable / backtracking content Definitely !Customization Yes, plenty of characters !Glitches / bugs Not at all.Worth price Full price !- Review below ----------------------------------------------------------------------The greatest Rayman ever !The level designs have greatly improved since Rayman Origins. You now have the help of Murfy the Greenbottle guy.So in this game you have a ranking whatever you played offline or not. Each world and each levels have their own cups and each cup give you points to level up your rank. You can get copper, silver, gold and also platinum cup. Also you earn cup doing online challenges, depending of your ranking at the end of each challenge.In this Rayman, you get some brand new worlds, levels, bosses and also a "karaoke" mode. The online challenge is pretty new too.So depending of the amount of lums you got at the end of a level, you get a cup. Also you need to save the teensies, all if you can. When you are good enough you unlock lucky tickets that may reward you with a random gift such as : a creature, lums, a teensy or a level of "Rayman Origins".You'll also unlock time trials levels, where you need to rush to the teensies before the evil foes launch them with rockets.At the end of each world you'll have a boss level fight and after that a "karaoke" level. The karaoke level, feature a music with "voices" if we call that voices, where you need to rush continuously until you reach the end. One of it great aspect is that the rhythm of the music and voices are linked to your moves."Back to Origins" world and levels are the replica of the original Rayman Origins levels. Only several levels are missing. In this one you'll find normal levels, shooting levels with the mosquito, rushing levels with the moving chest, and last levels with a boss at the end.Finally the online challenges will be required in order to have all achievements and it will take time until you reach the needed rank. Hopefully you can earn a lot of cups in a week and a lot of points if you're good enough. (16 cups each week)

content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
												Rayman Legends is a brilliant homage to the Rayman games before it and an excellent platformer on the whole. It's vibrant, colourful atmosphere makes you feel like a giddy 10-year-old and it's creative level design is both challenging and fun. The game has a phenomenal original soundtrack which rivals that of Bastion's, which is saying something. If you have any interest in platformers or just want to have fun then definitely pick this game up, it is nothing short of a masterpiece.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												NOTE: this review is written by a person who doesn't have any sentiments for Rayman having never played original Rayman titles on PS/PS2.i did, however, play previous Rayman game, Origins, and it was great. truly, a 5-star platforming experience. when i found out that there is a sequel on the way, i was all over it.i was playing on the launch day already, in fact, the two of us were. it's a great title to have fun while playing with family or friends and i highly recommend.(pros marked with '+', cons with '-')+ GRAPHICS.gorgeous, simply gorgeous. it was hella hard to beat the look of Rayman Origins, but Legends managed to do it. what's amazing too, it's that it has considerably low requirements for what it is, i play it on Intel HD Graphics completely fine.+ CONTROLS.works wonderfully, as you would expect from a game that has pretty difficult time attack levels.+ LEVEL DESIGN.platforming is amazing, it's tons more fun to do local co-op in this one. fighting is easy, but then again enemies aren't supposed to challenged you, they're rather obstacles in this game, similarly to barricades.my only gripe with level design is time attack/rush levels in co-op - the player who is slightly faster will always activate some events that lead to another player dying, at least we couldn't find a way around it. maybe it just requires being in complete sync, hehe.+ SOUND/MUSIC.music by itself is amazing. it's quite different from Rayman Origins, which had also had a stellar soundtrack, but while the first one was cutesy pitched-up singing, in Legends we platform to cinematic/orchestral top-notch quality music.special mention: musical levels are best thing to happen to platforming in a good while. Castle Rock is the best level in any platformer i ever played.+ CONTENT.there's quite a lot to do.collect 700 teensies - and it is pretty fun to do it. main levels have 8 (6 scattered across the level, 2 found in special puzzle rooms) in them, with time attack/rush/boss levels each having 3.collecting lums net you lottery tickets, which are a fun side activity - they unlock collectable creatures and also remastered levels from the previous Rayman game, Origins. yes, they are gated between the grind, as in you have to collect enough lums in each available level to get a ticket to get a chance to unlock a level, but without trying to get a maximum rating we easily unlocked more than 16 remastered levels by simply beating the levels.5 colourful words, each having two additional character unlocks, a boss level and a musical level. 6 world, as a bonus one, contains remixed musical levels. strangely enough, those are quite nauseating to play because of the fish-eye effect.there are lots of other unlockable characters as well.+ DIFFICULTY CURVE.Origins had one very annoying feature, or rather, lack of one. proper checkpoint system. often you had to redo way too long sections of the level, especially, if you missed a Teenie, and that was one of the reasons we couldn't finish all levels from it. i feel like Rayman Legends, while easier overall, is a good balanced game, and much, much less rage-inducing that it's predecessor.- STEAM INTEGRATION.yes, that is a con for me.i'd have loved getting achievements from this game. i'd love trading cards and background art for my profile from this game. i think workshop could have been pretty wonderful too, you know how many amazing talented people are there in the mod community.i must mention the uPlay thing. i hate being forced to use their DRM on top of Steam. it's unnecessary. and i'm never going to spend money on a platform, that is trying to force itself on me. i bypassed uPlay requirement in my own version, so i'm missing out on the leaderboards, but so be it. i don't consider this to be a fair requirement to begin with.- MINOR PORT SYNDROM.well, it was originally conceived for Wii U, only later brought to other platforms.this is not a major problem, trust me. the thing is. Murphy levels, which are based on QTEs and moving certain level props as you progress through them were originally controlled with special controller Wii U has. instead, in the port we control Murphy with a button push ('Y' on XBOX controller). sometimes he's focusing on the wrong platform depending on which player is ahead, and that can cause problems for players to progress at a slightly different pace.that's not too bad, but it could be better, simple as that.to sum up, it still is an amazing experience, despite the uPlay DRM inconviniences. i highly recommend it, this is a great, family-friendly, couch co-op experience that will net you many hours of enjoyment.9.5/10

content:
Posted: July 25, 2015
												+++ Fantastic art direction+++ Simple yet expansive controls that do a lot, with just a little+++ Healthy difficulty curve that culminates into a solid challenge without being overly frustrating+++ Varied levels each with their own special mechanic or focus--- Floaty controls, especially on narrow platforms--- Boss fights built on trial and errorRayman Legends is 'the' definitive modern platformer of the era.  It offers a clean experience without being too pure, it's loaded with goodies without getting bloated under the weight, and it stands out with its own signature rather than rely excessively on classic gaming references and nostalgia (excluding the 8-bit levels of course.)  The game is just right, just plain fun, and it never outstays its welcome.  A rare example of its kind, it's a delight for the casual and the hardcore alike.

Posted: June 30, 2014
												If you are looking for a PC platformer, this is a must have (even with everything we all hate about Uplay)I wanted to fill that Super Mario Bros. hole and although it took a couple of hours to really let Rayman Legends grow on me, this is easily one of the best games I own.  The momentum is naturally different from Mario and an attack throws things off initially but a half dozen levels or so and things will start feeling pretty natural.- Some of the best high resolution 2D art I've ever seen- Wide variety in levels (jumping, flying, swimming, timed, stealth, boss fights, even a Rockband inspired music level)- Non linear progression so you can do whatever you are in the mood for- Early and frequent character unlocks (key for me, as I'm not terribly fond of the original Rayman)- Challenge modes that make you feel like you are playing with other people work surpisingly well

content:
Posted: March 15, 2014
												Following off the glorious footsteps of the fantastic Rayman Origins, Rayman Legends successfully follows in the footsteps of its predecessor and delivers another high-quality entry into the Rayman franchise.The rebooted Rayman series are 2-D platformers that do away with the traditional lives and continue system in most platformers in favor of a fair balance of high yet-fair difficulty balanced out with a good checkpoint system, making the game more about overcoming obstacles rather than trying to beat a game in a single sitting. The spot-on controls make it so when you die, you feel it was your fault rather than the game messing up or the game being cheap.Since this game was originally planned as a Wii U exclusive, there are several stages that are clearly intended to be played on a touchscreen, which involve using longtime series character Murphy the fly to do tasks such as moving blocks, rotating wheels & cutting ropes. These features work perfectly fine on controller, but these particular levels are not nearly as engaging as the rest of the game.This game also supports four player co-op and has a fun multiplayer mini-game. Sadly, the multiplayer is only local. There is also a daily challenge mode that gives players the opportunity to complete with other players in several time trial courses complete with player ghosts to help feel the competitive spirit of the addicting game mode.This game has a great deal of content that can be enjoyed both in single player and multiplayer and is a title that deserves to be in your library.

												Where to begin...Ok ,let's start off with the most important part of the game: The content and HOLY SH*T, there's a lot to do in this game! - 6 main worlds with 10+ levels, each level having 10 well hidden Teensies to rescue, 600+ Lums to collect. - 2 Daily Challenges (normal and extreme) , 2 Weekly Challenges (normal and extreme).- Kung Foot multiplayer minigame.- Back to origins: 40 remade rayman origins levels.- 40+ "Speedrun" stage's.- 20+ Characters to unlock.There's more:- Everything is unlocked with a GENIUS unlocking system.- The controls are nearly perfect, very satisfying.- Level design is colorful, creative and chaotic.- One of the best soundtracks in video game history, the isn't a single track i don't like.- Music levels at the end of every world.The only negative thing about this game is Uplay, something that absolutely didn't annoy me a single bit.Just buy this masterpiece of a game, a review can't explain how great this game really is.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												I'm all for Rayman, I'm a fan of the original Rayman on the Atari Jaguar/PSX, it was colorful, and I was a huge fan of the very difficult and challenging nature of the platformer.  I have not played any other Rayman games except the original, so I'm not sure of those leading up to this game.  The art style in this game is very vivid and colorful, just like the original, which I really like.  The music is also okay, though I was not a huge fan, that is just personal preference.  The main "lobby" for selecting worlds and levels feels cluttered, like they just threw it together.  The movement is pretty good, my only gripe is that you can only charge your punch standing flat on the ground.  My main problems begin with level design.  They really like to use these chains/ropes which you can grab onto and slide down, but unfortunately if you even get CLOSE to anything that you can grab onto, it will auto grab whether you want to grab onto it or not, and you have to hold down and jump in order to let go.  After grabbing onto, say, a rope that you can slide on, you gain a lot of momentum almost instantly, which means if you are trying to get to something to the left, you have to let go of the rope and walk back, which, if there is an obstacle you have to jump over, you might accidentally grab onto the rope again and have to repeat this same process over and over.  It's not as though I fundamentally couldn't get past this obstacle, it's just that it happened often enough to be annoying, and that stacked up pretty quickly.  A lot of the levels consisted of me wanting to get to a secret area, but having to play around the frustrating issue of Rayman grabbing literally every rope handle and ledge in sight.  The level design isn't very interesting, every level blended together, felt pretty much the same, and left me bored very quickly.  Everything is very simple and quite easy, for the most part you can just hold down the run button and blast through all of the enemies without a second thought or ounce of difficulty.  They introduce a basic enemy right off the bat which is almost no threat at all whatsoever, I don't know how anyone could ever get hit by them.  Later on they give those enemies wooden shields, but you can just kick and one shot them just like the others, what is the point of them having shields if they are literally the same enemy and the shield does absolutely NOTHING?Basically, I just feel like I am just playing Super Rayman Bros. Wii U.  They don't really do anything interesting to pull you in and get you addicted and wanting to play more, it felt more like a chore going through each level like a zombie hoping that the next level would be exciting (never happened).  I will say, though, that this game would probably be best to play co-op with friends and not single player.  It seems to be designed with the exact same co-op as Super Mario Bros. Wii U (and the four five or six or how many other generic mario bros. platformers Nintendo made for the Wii, not including Galaxy of course, those games were a breath of fresh air).  Easy to say that I would not recommend a game that left me wanting to quit after getting halfway through the second world.  It's not interesting, it really doesn't introduce anything new or exciting, it's just, well, a generic, unmemorable platformer.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												As of late, the 2D platforming genre has seen a bit of a resurgence, especially in indie games like Super Meat Boy, I Wanna Be The Guy and to a lesser extent in more high-profile titles New Super Mario Bros. and the like. Rayman Legends, the sequel to 2011's reboot of the Rayman series, Rayman Origins, is one such platformer, and quite possibly one of the best in its genre. Rayman Legends, like its predecessor, is very simple in terms of its gameplay: Run, jump and punch your way through each of the levels, rescuing the small, fairy-like Teensies (who replace Origins' Electoons) as you go. It's actually quite a good thing the gameplay is this simple, because this game's difficulty is certainly not to be sniffed at. On some of the Challenge levels in particular it might take someone many different tries to get past a particular area of the game, and whilst at first this may seem aggravating there's no feeling quite like finally completing that ONE level. Another interesting addition is the Murfy mechanic - whilst playing, the player can use Murfy to guide their character through the level, by for instance moving platforms or distracting enemies, adding a little variety to the gameplay whilst still retaining the simplicity that makes it so enjoyable. There are also additional characters, but the differences are mostly cosmetic and don't change the gameplay, though in all honesty this is more to the game's benefit, since the gameplay is OK as it is, and doesn't really need any different character abilities to make it any better. Also like Origins, Legends' story is barebones, quite possibly to the overall game's benefit. Not focusing much on the story means that the player can divert their attention to actually enjoying the gameplay and uniquer art style, which are the game's main points. I have but two overarching criticisms of this version, however: First of all, the implementaion of the uPlay DRM system, even on the Steam version, which is unnecessary and cumbersome. Second: This game was clearly meant for the Wii U, a fact that shows as you play the game. I thought that maybe the Wii U's features would transfer more easily to the PC, but unfortunately Ubisoft didn't really take advantage of the keyboard ands mouse in the same way they took advantage of the Wii U's gamepad. Actions formerly performed by the player themselves as Murfy on the Touch Pad are now performed with a single touch of a button on the controller, which if you ask me is a bit of a missed opportunity. To summarise, despite clearly being designed for the Wii U, Rayman Legends is the best anyone could ask from a platforming game. It's challenging, it has funny characters, enjoyable levels, it doesn't focus too much on the plot, and most importantly - It will keep you entertained for a VERY long time. Yes, it can get very, VERY difficult, but as you play it, you realise that that's the whole point: Trial and error, improving with every failed attempt, slowly but surely perfecting your strategy. And it's exactly that that makes Rayman Legends special.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 10, 2014
Overall, I give this game a B-.  Noteworthy for strong platforming and aesthetics.  Very weak on plot, legacy, and characters.Very fun platformer, for sure.  Difficulty starts low but it ramps up as it goes, and the game feels challenging yet rewarding.  This is at its core, a platformer, though.  Don't expect much from combat and don't expect much from the boss fights.  The platforming itself is spot on, and arguably the game's best strength is its music levels (watch some videos to see yourself).  The visuals are breathtaking and just in style with Rayman, and the soundwork is equally top tier.  The platforming, art, and sound all definitely feel like Rayman, alright.  I give these an A.HOWEVERWhile this game looks, sounds, and plays like Rayman, thats as far as it goes.  If you are looking for a Rayman nostalgia trip, I wouldn't exactly say this is it.  Beyond what I mention above, this game holds little in common with its predessesors.  First off, Rayman Legends fails to live up to the tones of the previous games.  The trademark "grimdark hidden by a humorous and groovy world full of adventure and mystery" has been thrown out in favor of a completely light hearted and juvenile tone, but somehow isn't even big on the humor from previous games to make up for it.  Rayman Legends is as it implies; its all about adventure, mystery, and exploration, so it manages to keep those at least.  Its not about saving the world or laughing your♥♥♥♥♥off, its about running through various locations while you beat up random monsters that happen to find themselves in your way.  You won't feel much for the characters and they won't inspire you to feel much yourself.  Every character is a cookie cutter of the last; they offer no unique expressions or unique performance.  Rayman won't be offering his snarky comments and you won't get the comic relief you expect from Globox or the Teensies.  Villians from previous games do not make appereances.  None of the additional characters have anything to offer rather than a sentence of flavor text and are cookie cutter skins, and feel quite out of place given the Rayman universe.  Nobody even SAYS anything to characterize them or add any semblance of a plot.  The most plot you get is the order in which you play the levels and the progression between them.  I give the game's legacy, characters, and plot a D.  Note this game is still quite good, but its sad given that this game is literally half of Rayman; Rayman was known for its superior universe / tone AND its gameplay.Legends and Origins are supposed to be prequels to the 3D games, but since there is no dialogue or plot its highly arguable that this is a completely standalone title.  This dissappointed me quite a bit, since the game's sells itself as Rayman's "origins" and "legend."  Please keep that in mind when purchasing this product.Also if you are eyeing Origins, don't bother since this game includes Origins.Another thing that might really get on your nerves is that because of the game's target audience, there are a bunch of really dumb minigames that the game is constantly shoving in your face, such as the Monster Room or the Lucky Ticket game.  In fact, in order to even play the Origins half of the game you must play that minigame around 100 times.Overall, I give this game a B-.  Noteworthy for strong platforming and aesthetics.  Very weak on plot, legacy, and characters.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												This games is misrepresented and badly advertised. Not only does the store page not have any clear labeling of the forced uplay instalation outside the small greyed out print at the very bottom of the screen, the games crashes on startup if you are connected to the interent. This can be avoided by disabling the LAN/WiFi connection on your PC and disconnecting yourself from the internet and then launhing the game. Releasing a game in this state is not right from any company but from the likes of a Triple-A publisher like Ubisoft this is an insult to the paying customer. It also cannot be played in fullscreen on 1080p monitors when using AMD graphics cards without significant adjustment either. As standard this game runs at 50hz in fullscreen 1080p forcing a black frame around the screen. This can be fixed by setting up a Custom Resolution in the AMD Catalyst Control Center. You can also run the game in windowed mode in which case the game is displayed correctly at 1080p and 60hz, but the game does not have an option for full screen windowed either so this also presents the game in a less than optimal maner. Again there is a fix, and again it involves the use of external applications to fix the problems created uncaring and bad developers, you need an application to firce full screen borderless windowed like "Borderless Gaming" and "Fullscreenizer".This of course is not an issue for Nvidia users, Ubisoft are openly backed by Nvidia and their software solutions, it is only an issue for AMD graphics cards. This is basic stuff and the developers have made a mess of it. They have had years since the release of the game and still these issues have not been fixed. This game is not worth the money, clearly they are not using it to produce complete and working games. Do not buy this game.

content:
Posted: March 4, 2014
												Unfortunately this game crashes upon launch for me.  I have tried to contact Ubisoft Support and they have told me that there is no fix for this issue.Others on their forums are also complaining of this issue, and the official statement has been to "Disable internet before launching the game, and start Uplay in Offline mode".  When done, the game *does* launch (and it's a GLORIOUS game).  This is quite possibly one of my favorite couch co-op games, similar to a less-frustrating Super Mario Bros Wii in that each player tries to complete the level simultaneously, but can punch or inhibit other players if they want to be mean.  The game has very excellent controls, vibrant and varied visuals, and a stellar soundtrack.  Upon completing each stage you are rewarded with a "musical" level that requires you to keep the beat almost like a platformer Guitar Hero.However, despite my glowing review, I cannot in good faith give this game a recommendation until Ubisoft does something about the Crash On Launch issue that turns launching the game into a chore.

												Today's Review: Rayman: LegendsOverview: Rayman Legends inmediatly stands out as one of the BEST platform games ever created, everything about the games has been pulished at the point the seek to release a game purely fun, adictive and really adaptative to the different capabilities of every player, making this one a fun-as-hell game.Graphics: Dazzlig. This game was made following Rayman Origins model and work pretty well! of course the detail fit to the type of game this is which is of course not COD Ghosts but it manages to get a really satisfiying quality and the result of years of working on ubisoft really pays off.Music: Maybe the best part of the game, the music is simply 1 world: Awesome! You have deep tone balades and some amazing rock for times you just enjoy the moments were you complete a level and you get rewarded with rayman dancing, making the sountrack one of the best available.Story: The story follows the line of the Rayman series, the world is threaten again and Rayman (and friends) must wake up to save it from the evil (things?) that swarm the peaceful world. Really the story is just a background for the game and does not really affect, every person that have played the previous versions of rayman knows that there's no need for an excuse to kill the bad things and save the good ones.Metascore: 90/100 "Maybe the actual 39.99 it's a bit high, the game worth it but a sale of 75% it's deffinetly the moment to get this game and you MUST get this game".

												Game has great art and has some nice music but has some serious problems which render it a frustrating and un-fun experience. The gameplay mechanics are inconstant and lack depth. Simple things like not being able to do a charge attack upwards shows how little polish the game has. The running attack mechanic is poorly designed and flings you forward causing you to lose the ability to accurately land after a run attack. You can't "hang" off ledges, which means you will spend a lot of time accidentally running off cliffs when you simply meant to get close to the edge.Collecting random garbage is NOT fun. The game ranks you based on how many fairies and mini guys you grab but at no point do you feel rewarded for collecting these things. The fairies are ONLY used to unlock characters which don't have any different abilities or anything unique about them. The mini guys that you find unlock levels but having to find 10 of them per level makes the task feel like a chore instead of a game. Overall you spend the majority of your time collecting items that serve little purpose.Enemies? What enemies? The enemies in this game are WAY too easy. It is almost impossible to die from them as they don't attack back, rarely move, and have such a short range of attack. The game would be more fun if you didn't have an attack button and actually had to land on the enemies heads, at least this would give them a shred of difficulty.The saving in this game is absolute trash. Did you just spend 10 minutes collecting all the random garbage in an area. Well you better not die because if you do you will have to collect all of it again. In almost every other modern platformer I have played the things you collect are saved but you are returned to an earlier checkpoint. Making you go back and have to recollect every item is terrible design. Not to mention replaying the music over and over which is annoying to say the least.90% of the levels are a complete bore and lack creativity.  Each world introduces some new level mechanic but none of these mechanics are really "fun". Flying = boring. Sneaking = boring. Hitting Y to move some element in the level = oh god so boring. Compare this game to any other platformer and you will see more creativity in one level than you would in this entire game. Overall the game can be summed with two words "not fun". It doesn't hold a candle to  Braid, Super Mario, Little Big Planet and many other modern platformers.  It is a step back in patforming and I am surprised that people have given it such high praise.

												The game has a large some of fun levels. Funny as well. Though the few annoying ones make this game not worth getting. I feel as if they did not test this game properly. There are these time trial based areas in which you have 40 seconds to save the three teensies. Most of which are doable on around the third or forth try, some take a bit more. However a select few require sitting for maybe an hour or more endlessly trying to even finish. Taking a break doesn't help, you lose the rhythm of the course.  If you want something with sever difficulty curves bend inward, this game is worth a try. Otherwise don't waste your time.

Posted: March 21
												Super fun and addictive 2d platformer with nice graphics and amazing daily/weekly challenge system that helps you keep interst in game. The music themed levels is just brilliant.Having said that, it's very easy to ruin all fun-factor for you just when you starting to push the game to its limits and try to 100% complete levels (collect 600 lums & 10 teensies). That's when you start to notice overall sloppiness in controls of your character and unregistered commands from time to time.I like this game alot and it's great for local-coop but I just can't recommend it for someone else. If you some kind of OCD-100%-platinum-all-trophys-completionist be prepared that late in game levels would be hard without any reasons for it.

content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
												Many problems hit me as I played this Legends.- The level of difficulty is way too low. I understand that the first levels need to be easy for everyone to get used to the controls. But I never really had problem moving forward.- The level select screen is completely unoriginal. This might sound like a detail, but it really is a pain.- It is way less fun than Origin.- It counts too much on the Origin levels to last in time, I would have prefered more level in the main campain.- The level design is not as inspired as Origin. The thing is, Origin was so good, and this one is so OK, that I cannot recommend it. Sure the music are great (even if some are taken from Origin, again), the animation is beautiful, and there are loads of playable characters. This game introduces some very interesting features. But if you have a choice to make, prefer Origin to Legends.

Posted: March 3
												Rayman Legends is a really good sequel to another really good game (Rayman Origins).But in my opinion i think Ubisoft need more 3D Rayman games like Rayman 2: The Great Escape and Rayman 3: Hoodlum Havoc. I like the challenges minigames though, they give the game more replay value because everyday and week there are new and fun challenges. The story is... well it's ok. I liked the first storyline way more but this is still ok.One thing i really think Ubisoft need to look at is ALL THE ♥♥♥♥ING HACKERS IN CHALLENGES!Sure they sometimes get banned but not all of them and this really grinds my gears.Other than that, it is just a pretty well made sequel to Rayman Origins with similar style but there are more levels and the graphics are a little bit more detailed. It also introduces a new character; Barbara.A small thing that annoyed me is that Xbox One controllers are not supported and only Xbox 360. So you will need something like Xpadder for it to work.Conclusion:Rayman Legends is a fun 2D adventure game that most people can both play and enjoy.I will give it 8.5/10.

												The game is very fun to play by your own and with friends the controller setup is easy you literally just plug it in and the game will find it but i had a problem with the game recognizing the controller as the first player. The game overall lacks some story i have only played the first set of levels but through all the levels they didn't seem to link together very well or start with a story or cut-scene to explain why you start there i also got  introduced to a villain witch you didn't know existed.The game works around a area with magic paintings which take you to different areas it has a feel of a ipod/android game were you can collect and unlock various things and complete daily challenges to get more lums.The introduction of the new character was annoying you saved a little thing ( i forgot there names ) and unlocked the new character, the character had absolutely nothing to do with the game but instead was an option character to play which annoyed me because i expected some kind of awesome saving thing or at-least an introduction to the character. It would of been cool to have that character have different moves or a special ability but nope :(The game is very fun dont get me wrong but i just wish it had some integrity to the levels ( seamless level transitions ) and to the characters ( character introduction and ai partner ).

Posted: April 14, 2014
												Every time I play this game, I'm just amazed at the amount of the love, care and attention that was so clearly poured into it. Every single level - and there's TONNES, even before you consider the fact that many (all?) of Rayman Origins' brilliant levels are also included - all have their own personality, and you're never left feeling like the game is just going through the motions. The music-themed levels that cap each of the game's worlds are an absolute highlight - if platforming set to a mariachi cover of Eye of the Tiger doesn't whet your whistle, I'm not sure what else I could possibly say. Suffice to say, I want this game to last forever, and I'm reviewing it with the sole purpose of hopefully convincing others to try it as well. One of the best games of the last decade, and one of the best plaformers of all time.

Posted: April 13, 2014
												Rayman Legends is a fun, addictive game, that improves upon the originals with slightly improved graphics using the beautiful UbiArt Engine. The level design as well music are fantastic, A few shortcoming held it back from completle greatness, but I still thorougly enjoyed it.Foremost, the interesting level design really shines with the varied levels that you have to overcome. The goals is always the same if not slight different. Rescue a certain number of teensies by finding the secret rooms as well as scouring the level for invisible walls and areas . The journey is accomplishing this and there is nothing better then finding them all  and getting 100% on the level. Other levels of interest are the boss levels as well as the timed ones that keep the variety up. Continuing on, the music levels that you find at the end of each area in the game are fabulous and are always something to look forward to as well as challenging in their own right. Lastly, the simple fair gameplay and tight controls. Everything required for a great platformer. Xbox controller is what I used and what I would recommend althought I'm sure keyboard works fine.For the negatives I wouldn't really say they are complete negatives, but something that people like me will have to learn to live with. There is a lot of online/leaderboard type integration. There are dailies and weeklies. They are indeed fun and definetly challenging. By doing them you are rewarded with lums which are used for unlocking differnt characters in the game that you can play as.The majority can be unlocked just by beating the game but there are a few that require you to do them for awhile. Although I have no idea if these characters are worth the effort or if there mere recolors they are considered superior in terms of cost and I would assume they are pretty good. The positives of this is there is added gametime to the game as well as a stretch goal if you really enjoy it. The negative is not everything is unlocked right after beating the game which means you were probably wont go back unless you really are dedicated. Definetly the most frustrating thing would have to be the Back to Origins levels. While all the good levels in the original Rayman Origins are included they are not unlocked right away. You will unlock all of them sometime after you've beaten the game which means you cant play them in their original order until then. This is extremely frustating as after you beat the final boss and done the extra world the last thing you want to do is go back and 100% those levels that you have done before if you played the original. It would of been a lot better if they were unlocked in order after beating each area of the main game. At the very least I am happy they are included in game as extra content and I applaud the devolopers for not making someone purchase Rayman Legends if they want to experience it.Kind of ranted on about the negatives, but I figure people know or have heard about how great is and should hear a different side. Definetly worth the puchase!8.5/10

Posted: April 5, 2014
												This game is simply AMAZING. Absolutely fantastic. This is EXACTLY how you make a sequel to a good game!Firstly, the artwork of the game is just like Rayman Origins, only there's a lot more detail going on here to make the colors and art style mesh a bit more together. That being said, the artwork is beautiful and despite the main characters' very colorful, silly appearance, the settings and areas match them so well that it's hard to say that they feel out of place. The music is just as good, and also brings a more thematic feel to the game, seeing as how Legends takes a bit more of a civilization styled world as opposed to the open wilderness areas that Origins featured. The soundtrack fits each world nicely, nailing a variety of genres and styles almost perfectly. My only complaints with the music would be the oddly off-putting Invasion level songs, which don't seem as urgent as they're supposed to feel.As a modern platformer game, the amount of levels in the game is extremely important, and Legends most certainly didn't disappoint. There's TONS of levels in the game spanning over five unique worlds, and for those who dearly miss the content from Rayman: Origins, there's 60 levels from Origins included in the game to satisfy both crowds. Legends' levels also add a bit more challenge to the levels which partly secures my previous complaint on the easiness of Origins' levels. Though some levels still did feel a bit too easy, I feel the challenge is still decent in the game for what it was going for; a game to please both casual and hardcore players.The amount of unlockables in the game is a great deal more than Origins, but it is a bit lacking. Once you've unlocked all of the normal levels, and the Origins levels, the only other things to get include costumes for the four main characters, though they aren't that special as many of the costumes follow a set theme with each of the characters, such as a Knight costume for Rayman and Globox, a Caveman costume for the Teensies, Rayman and Globox, a Dark Rayman and Dark Globox costume, etc. As far as the methods to unlock them go, it all depends on how much you've played the game as most of the costumes are locked behind a set amount of Lums collected to unlock them, going all the way up to 1 million lums for the final Rayman costume. Collecting all 700 Teensies also rewards you with a costume, which I think is pretty underwhelming. Though the Warrior Princess characters are just different costumes for Barbara, I do like the different amounts of variety in clothing, hair styles and colors they use with each of them. It's a nice touch and they at least added more than 2 extra costumes for Rayman this time.The game plays very fluently, the controls are very well thought out and easy to use, so most of the gameplay is reliant on the player's skill. I've never felt like any death in the game was on part of bad level design or poor control design as they're damn good. I would recommend that people play the game with a gamepad though as playing with the keyboard can get a bit awkward.Speaking of level design and levels, the way they presented the levels in each of the worlds was fantastic. Although each world spanned across at least 10 different paintings that counted as levels, I felt as though I was transitioning from one part of the world's story to the next. Additionally I will say that each world seems to have it's own story, rather than seeming like each world is connected somehow. It makes it seem like each world is separate from the others moreso than just in setting and appearance and gives the game some actual life and a sense of freedom and adventure despite being in a large tent with a bunch of old, crusty paintings.My absolute favorite part of this game that got me hyped were the ingenious music levels, where every action int he level is set to the beat and rhythm of a song, remixed in a very special way for each world's music level. Though there's only a handful of music levels in the game, I feel like this isn't a bad thing as each music level plays out fantastically. The look of sheer joy on my face when I realized that the song playing in the level Castle Rock was a Rayman style remix of "Black Betty" is something I can never forget. And although the music levels are seen as the biggest selling point of Rayman Legends, Ubisoft went the extra mile to ensure that they put effort in all of the levels, and used the music levels as a lure for players, which makes the game that much richer in the experience.In terms of story, I'm willing to forgive Rayman Legends for its very basic storyline. Rayman games never exactly had a great story to them, and the fact that there's no set canon of the Rayman games just adds to the charm, which this game is chock full of. The basic goal of the game seems to intertwine itself with the individual stories that come along with each of the worlds.The Challenges and Kung Foot modes of the game add a bit more of a competitive side to Rayman Legends. Competing in different challenges every day and week for a chance to be seen at the top of the leaderboards is very nice, but I feel the PC version's Challenge mode is sort of sullied with the rise of many cheaters, especially in timed Challenges. I don't consider timed Challenges of any sort to be very serious on the PC version as people just cheat to get sub 10-second times as opposed to the people who actually have skill and talent in the game. Lum collection and Distance endurance challenges are just fine though as it's very hard to seem like one's cheating at these challenges as they can be done at one's own pace.I don't have any experience with Kung Foot though as I haven't had the chance to play this game with multiple people.In conclusion, this game is absolutely fantastic. Rayman Legends is a damn good example of how to make an excellent sequel to a good game. Legends builds upon the foundation and base of the original Rayman Origins and addresses many other issues that Origins had and aims very high to correct them. I would certainly say that Rayman Legends is much better than Origins, despite Origins also being an excellent game in its own right.Oh, as an additional warning, you have to make a separate U-Play account in order to play the game from Steam, which I honestly find annoying and a little pointless.Overall I'd give this game a 10/10

Posted: May 22, 2014
												Really good platformer that shows an amazing amount of effort put forward both artistically and level designs. The music is fantastic, topped off only by having a few special levels that revolve around the music. The game is packed with a lot of fun and a lot of laughs, I love Origins and Legends is certainly a worthy sequel with a lot of charm to it. Other platformers certainly seem to have gotten lazy with their games, where one would struggle to know which one is which if they didnt' see the title screen. This one shows effort and is worth the buy. I cannot reccomend this game enough if you like platformers whether it be Sonic, Mario, Commander Keen,  previous Rayman titles etc. It's a great co-op and solo game and don't worry unlike the New Super Mario Bros games, you do not bounce off eachother, you actually have moves to help. You can slap one another ...but, if used right it can actually save your butt. It's worth noting both Rayman Legends and Origin are worth having together, there are SOME levels from Origins you unlock in Legends. But there's a lot of fun to have with both- so get on it! DRM NOTE:This game requires Uplay to launch, which is incredibly irritating. On top of steam a mini-Uplay client needs to boot and often you'll find yourself waiting for Uplay to update before you get a chance to play your game. This counter productive move really ruins the whole idea of steam keeping games up to date when Ubisofts -DRM ontop of DRM- has to update seperately so it can triple check you're not a thief. This is of course is only highlighing my frustration when you know there's pirates playing this who do not have to sit through any of this and just enjoy the game that they didn't pay for but I did.

Posted: January 3, 2014
												This game is definitly in my top games of the year list, and is probably the best 2D Platformer I ever played.The bad stuf first: You need UPlay, which is a stupid annoyance and this game is not so nice to play with a keyboard. I really recommend a controller.That out of the way: WOWEasy to pick up and play -  had a stressful day? Play one or two of the music levels and you'll feel releaxed and calm.Want a challenge? My controller has toothmarks from some of the time trial levels which get unlocked later on.But still the game is never unfair or discourages you so you just keep coming back until you get that sweet sensation of finally beating the level. And when you have you can go to the daily challenges and compete against other players.One thing I like to point out is the level design. Especially in the music levels but also in every other, theres a certain flow. You're almost playing yourself into meditation. Rayman Origins, I felt, had to much backtracking so that you get all the lums and unlocked more stuff. Here you have much less lums you have to collect to get a gold medal, so you can just play the game. Even finding the caged Teensies isn't pulling you out of the flow.On top: The visuals are just.... happy. Nothing against dark and gritty games, I love them, but this game is radiating with happiness and joy. In the animations, the background, the enemys. Everything just says: Have a good time - and you definitly will. Solo or with friends.If you have doubt: Play the demo, but I can't find a reason why not to like this game.

Posted: March 29, 2014
												I feel that there is only one way to describe this game: classic.The controls are nice and tight. Levels are a blast. Character and environment designs are whimsical and quirky. It's sometimes challenging, but not in the nail-biting "Dark Souls" way but in the "whoops I messed up that move, let's keep going cause this is fun" kind of way. Overall, the feel of the game makes you just want to keep playing and playing.It's just really, really fun. I would definitely consider this a huge step up from Rayman Origins, which is also a pretty phenomenal game, though I think this game makes Origin obsolete since it includes unlockable remastered Origin levels.A side note, the pop culture references this game makes are pretty amusing. The swimming levels are pretty much a throwback to Crash Bandicoot: Warped's scuba diving levels (too bad they control just as badly with a keyboard though, but tbh I haven't really seen that many "aqua combat" sequences in games that were actually fun). Also, the guys behind this game must have either really loved or hated Dreamwork's How to Train Your Dragon movie, hahaha.

Posted: June 26, 2014
												This is a game of rare quality. Unless you've lived under a rock these past few years, you know Ubisoft rebooted the Rayman franchise in 2011 with the critically acclaimed Rayman Origins. This game saw the limbless hero of many games in my childhood return to his platformer roots. The game was visually stunning and challenging with a superb soundtrack to boot. And now we have Rayman Legends. This game is quite literally the logical next step for the reboot of this franchise. It still has the cartoony visuals, but this time it looks like you're watching a moving painting instead of a colourful cartoon. The level design is top notch and can be very challenging at times (which led to frustration in my case. Not that that is necessarily a bad thing as it made overcoming these obtacles that much sweeter) and oh my God is the soundtrack even better than the last one. Everything just breathes atmosphere and polish and the attential to graphical detail and the interaction between what happens on the screen and the music/sound design is nothing short of a victory in game design. Well done.So, for a fair price you get a whole plethora of levels set in different worlds, loads of collectibles, online rankings (with daily and weekly challenges) and a host of levels from Rayman Origins with updated visuals. In short: best platform game in recent memory. Worth every penny.

Posted: April 14, 2014
												Every time I play this game, I'm just amazed at the amount of the love, care and attention that was so clearly poured into it. Every single level - and there's TONNES, even before you consider the fact that many (all?) of Rayman Origins' brilliant levels are also included - all have their own personality, and you're never left feeling like the game is just going through the motions. The music-themed levels that cap each of the game's worlds are an absolute highlight - if platforming set to a mariachi cover of Eye of the Tiger doesn't whet your whistle, I'm not sure what else I could possibly say. Suffice to say, I want this game to last forever, and I'm reviewing it with the sole purpose of hopefully convincing others to try it as well. One of the best games of the last decade, and one of the best plaformers of all time.

Posted: April 13, 2014
												Rayman Legends is a fun, addictive game, that improves upon the originals with slightly improved graphics using the beautiful UbiArt Engine. The level design as well music are fantastic, A few shortcoming held it back from completle greatness, but I still thorougly enjoyed it.Foremost, the interesting level design really shines with the varied levels that you have to overcome. The goals is always the same if not slight different. Rescue a certain number of teensies by finding the secret rooms as well as scouring the level for invisible walls and areas . The journey is accomplishing this and there is nothing better then finding them all  and getting 100% on the level. Other levels of interest are the boss levels as well as the timed ones that keep the variety up. Continuing on, the music levels that you find at the end of each area in the game are fabulous and are always something to look forward to as well as challenging in their own right. Lastly, the simple fair gameplay and tight controls. Everything required for a great platformer. Xbox controller is what I used and what I would recommend althought I'm sure keyboard works fine.For the negatives I wouldn't really say they are complete negatives, but something that people like me will have to learn to live with. There is a lot of online/leaderboard type integration. There are dailies and weeklies. They are indeed fun and definetly challenging. By doing them you are rewarded with lums which are used for unlocking differnt characters in the game that you can play as.The majority can be unlocked just by beating the game but there are a few that require you to do them for awhile. Although I have no idea if these characters are worth the effort or if there mere recolors they are considered superior in terms of cost and I would assume they are pretty good. The positives of this is there is added gametime to the game as well as a stretch goal if you really enjoy it. The negative is not everything is unlocked right after beating the game which means you were probably wont go back unless you really are dedicated. Definetly the most frustrating thing would have to be the Back to Origins levels. While all the good levels in the original Rayman Origins are included they are not unlocked right away. You will unlock all of them sometime after you've beaten the game which means you cant play them in their original order until then. This is extremely frustating as after you beat the final boss and done the extra world the last thing you want to do is go back and 100% those levels that you have done before if you played the original. It would of been a lot better if they were unlocked in order after beating each area of the main game. At the very least I am happy they are included in game as extra content and I applaud the devolopers for not making someone purchase Rayman Legends if they want to experience it.Kind of ranted on about the negatives, but I figure people know or have heard about how great is and should hear a different side. Definetly worth the puchase!8.5/10

Posted: April 5, 2014
												This game is simply AMAZING. Absolutely fantastic. This is EXACTLY how you make a sequel to a good game!Firstly, the artwork of the game is just like Rayman Origins, only there's a lot more detail going on here to make the colors and art style mesh a bit more together. That being said, the artwork is beautiful and despite the main characters' very colorful, silly appearance, the settings and areas match them so well that it's hard to say that they feel out of place. The music is just as good, and also brings a more thematic feel to the game, seeing as how Legends takes a bit more of a civilization styled world as opposed to the open wilderness areas that Origins featured. The soundtrack fits each world nicely, nailing a variety of genres and styles almost perfectly. My only complaints with the music would be the oddly off-putting Invasion level songs, which don't seem as urgent as they're supposed to feel.As a modern platformer game, the amount of levels in the game is extremely important, and Legends most certainly didn't disappoint. There's TONS of levels in the game spanning over five unique worlds, and for those who dearly miss the content from Rayman: Origins, there's 60 levels from Origins included in the game to satisfy both crowds. Legends' levels also add a bit more challenge to the levels which partly secures my previous complaint on the easiness of Origins' levels. Though some levels still did feel a bit too easy, I feel the challenge is still decent in the game for what it was going for; a game to please both casual and hardcore players.The amount of unlockables in the game is a great deal more than Origins, but it is a bit lacking. Once you've unlocked all of the normal levels, and the Origins levels, the only other things to get include costumes for the four main characters, though they aren't that special as many of the costumes follow a set theme with each of the characters, such as a Knight costume for Rayman and Globox, a Caveman costume for the Teensies, Rayman and Globox, a Dark Rayman and Dark Globox costume, etc. As far as the methods to unlock them go, it all depends on how much you've played the game as most of the costumes are locked behind a set amount of Lums collected to unlock them, going all the way up to 1 million lums for the final Rayman costume. Collecting all 700 Teensies also rewards you with a costume, which I think is pretty underwhelming. Though the Warrior Princess characters are just different costumes for Barbara, I do like the different amounts of variety in clothing, hair styles and colors they use with each of them. It's a nice touch and they at least added more than 2 extra costumes for Rayman this time.The game plays very fluently, the controls are very well thought out and easy to use, so most of the gameplay is reliant on the player's skill. I've never felt like any death in the game was on part of bad level design or poor control design as they're damn good. I would recommend that people play the game with a gamepad though as playing with the keyboard can get a bit awkward.Speaking of level design and levels, the way they presented the levels in each of the worlds was fantastic. Although each world spanned across at least 10 different paintings that counted as levels, I felt as though I was transitioning from one part of the world's story to the next. Additionally I will say that each world seems to have it's own story, rather than seeming like each world is connected somehow. It makes it seem like each world is separate from the others moreso than just in setting and appearance and gives the game some actual life and a sense of freedom and adventure despite being in a large tent with a bunch of old, crusty paintings.My absolute favorite part of this game that got me hyped were the ingenious music levels, where every action int he level is set to the beat and rhythm of a song, remixed in a very special way for each world's music level. Though there's only a handful of music levels in the game, I feel like this isn't a bad thing as each music level plays out fantastically. The look of sheer joy on my face when I realized that the song playing in the level Castle Rock was a Rayman style remix of "Black Betty" is something I can never forget. And although the music levels are seen as the biggest selling point of Rayman Legends, Ubisoft went the extra mile to ensure that they put effort in all of the levels, and used the music levels as a lure for players, which makes the game that much richer in the experience.In terms of story, I'm willing to forgive Rayman Legends for its very basic storyline. Rayman games never exactly had a great story to them, and the fact that there's no set canon of the Rayman games just adds to the charm, which this game is chock full of. The basic goal of the game seems to intertwine itself with the individual stories that come along with each of the worlds.The Challenges and Kung Foot modes of the game add a bit more of a competitive side to Rayman Legends. Competing in different challenges every day and week for a chance to be seen at the top of the leaderboards is very nice, but I feel the PC version's Challenge mode is sort of sullied with the rise of many cheaters, especially in timed Challenges. I don't consider timed Challenges of any sort to be very serious on the PC version as people just cheat to get sub 10-second times as opposed to the people who actually have skill and talent in the game. Lum collection and Distance endurance challenges are just fine though as it's very hard to seem like one's cheating at these challenges as they can be done at one's own pace.I don't have any experience with Kung Foot though as I haven't had the chance to play this game with multiple people.In conclusion, this game is absolutely fantastic. Rayman Legends is a damn good example of how to make an excellent sequel to a good game. Legends builds upon the foundation and base of the original Rayman Origins and addresses many other issues that Origins had and aims very high to correct them. I would certainly say that Rayman Legends is much better than Origins, despite Origins also being an excellent game in its own right.Oh, as an additional warning, you have to make a separate U-Play account in order to play the game from Steam, which I honestly find annoying and a little pointless.Overall I'd give this game a 10/10
