Posted: March 18, 2014
												While I prefer the art direction of Origins over Legends (the cel-shaded cartoon look was just SO good), this is by far the better of the two games if you're one of those that has to gold every level.  In some ways it's a lot easier to do so, but at the same time, Origins did some seriously nasty things requiring you to play a level down to a science.  Legends allows you to take a few bumps from time to time and still come out on top.  Whether or not you think that's good or bad depends on the type of gamer you are.The other things you can expect are normal for a Rayman game - tight controls, great humor, heaps upon HEAPS of levels to run through, a bajillion collectible items, AND remixes of select levels from Origins (only this time without any King Lums).If you're totally new to Rayman, I would recommend Legends without blinking.  If you're a bit more of the hardcore platformer, go with Origins.  Or get both!  These are two of the most solid 2D platformers on the market today.

Posted: September 10, 2013
												WARNING: uplay DRM, may the creators of it burn in hell.I find myself at a loss of words here. The game is so amazing I don't know how to even convey my impressions, which are positive in every possible way. The game has everything you would want from a sequel to Rayman Origins: a lot of levels full of crazy platforming, fun challenges and smooth difficulty curve, beautiful art style which manages to blend parallax 2D sceneries with 3D bosses perfectly, and the music which is not only amazing on its own, but fits the style of the game perfectly and highlights the crazyness of the action. The game even has a good share of levels from Rayman Origins added as a bonus, reworked to feel like a part of the new game experience (even those annoying mosquito levels aren't annoying anymore).And yes, Rayman Legends has its amount of re used assets from Rayman Origins, both graphics and sound wise, but it is still an astonishing game with a lot of new good stuff added to the mix.All in all: well designed, well executed and damn compelling.

Posted: February 2, 2014
												Best platforming game I have ever played. Excellent audiovisual art direction (music is a work of genius). Whole game can be played cooperatively by 2 players (with fun soccer minigame up to 4 players as a bonus). It gets challenging hard really fast, but repeating is not frustrating - game makes you want to play. At the end of every chapter that consists of typical platforming gameplay there is one "music" level where you have to play according to rhythm of music that is playing - excellent idea, too bad there are so few of those. Technically game has some downsides - max res is 1080p, max framerate is 60HZ. This, of course, is dictated by hand made animations and graphics. Platforming genre, like no other, could really make use of 120Hz and beyond with some motion blur reducing technology (like ULMB) :(Another downside is that Ubisoft insists on putting Uplay on their every game even if you buy it on Steam :( This is the game that converts people into gamers.

Posted: April 14, 2014
												Every time I play this game, I'm just amazed at the amount of the love, care and attention that was so clearly poured into it. Every single level - and there's TONNES, even before you consider the fact that many (all?) of Rayman Origins' brilliant levels are also included - all have their own personality, and you're never left feeling like the game is just going through the motions. The music-themed levels that cap each of the game's worlds are an absolute highlight - if platforming set to a mariachi cover of Eye of the Tiger doesn't whet your whistle, I'm not sure what else I could possibly say. Suffice to say, I want this game to last forever, and I'm reviewing it with the sole purpose of hopefully convincing others to try it as well. One of the best games of the last decade, and one of the best plaformers of all time.

Posted: June 29, 2014
												Oh. My. God.This game is fantastic! I love everything about it, from the cute cartoony style, to the barely visible make-it-up-as-you-go story, to the total general bad♥♥♥♥♥ness of everything you do. But beware: this game is not easy. It is one of the only games I have ever rage-quit, and I am completely unable to get past Ninja Grand-Master Temple. But it doesn't matter. When replaying levels is just as fun as playing them for the first time, with new cool characters available at every turn, and with a race of creatures so cute that it will make you weep for hours (the Teensies), this game offers entertainment for all ages, forever.And the musical maps. See the first line. They defy description. Have you ever wanted to bounce through a giant swamp, and land on the head of a giant toad, on the beat? And feel like it's you, not the game, doing that? It's just amazing.I love this game, and would buy it again.But beware.

Posted: April 5, 2014
												This game is simply AMAZING. Absolutely fantastic. This is EXACTLY how you make a sequel to a good game!Firstly, the artwork of the game is just like Rayman Origins, only there's a lot more detail going on here to make the colors and art style mesh a bit more together. That being said, the artwork is beautiful and despite the main characters' very colorful, silly appearance, the settings and areas match them so well that it's hard to say that they feel out of place. The music is just as good, and also brings a more thematic feel to the game, seeing as how Legends takes a bit more of a civilization styled world as opposed to the open wilderness areas that Origins featured. The soundtrack fits each world nicely, nailing a variety of genres and styles almost perfectly. My only complaints with the music would be the oddly off-putting Invasion level songs, which don't seem as urgent as they're supposed to feel.As a modern platformer game, the amount of levels in the game is extremely important, and Legends most certainly didn't disappoint. There's TONS of levels in the game spanning over five unique worlds, and for those who dearly miss the content from Rayman: Origins, there's 60 levels from Origins included in the game to satisfy both crowds. Legends' levels also add a bit more challenge to the levels which partly secures my previous complaint on the easiness of Origins' levels. Though some levels still did feel a bit too easy, I feel the challenge is still decent in the game for what it was going for; a game to please both casual and hardcore players.The amount of unlockables in the game is a great deal more than Origins, but it is a bit lacking. Once you've unlocked all of the normal levels, and the Origins levels, the only other things to get include costumes for the four main characters, though they aren't that special as many of the costumes follow a set theme with each of the characters, such as a Knight costume for Rayman and Globox, a Caveman costume for the Teensies, Rayman and Globox, a Dark Rayman and Dark Globox costume, etc. As far as the methods to unlock them go, it all depends on how much you've played the game as most of the costumes are locked behind a set amount of Lums collected to unlock them, going all the way up to 1 million lums for the final Rayman costume. Collecting all 700 Teensies also rewards you with a costume, which I think is pretty underwhelming. Though the Warrior Princess characters are just different costumes for Barbara, I do like the different amounts of variety in clothing, hair styles and colors they use with each of them. It's a nice touch and they at least added more than 2 extra costumes for Rayman this time.The game plays very fluently, the controls are very well thought out and easy to use, so most of the gameplay is reliant on the player's skill. I've never felt like any death in the game was on part of bad level design or poor control design as they're damn good. I would recommend that people play the game with a gamepad though as playing with the keyboard can get a bit awkward.Speaking of level design and levels, the way they presented the levels in each of the worlds was fantastic. Although each world spanned across at least 10 different paintings that counted as levels, I felt as though I was transitioning from one part of the world's story to the next. Additionally I will say that each world seems to have it's own story, rather than seeming like each world is connected somehow. It makes it seem like each world is separate from the others moreso than just in setting and appearance and gives the game some actual life and a sense of freedom and adventure despite being in a large tent with a bunch of old, crusty paintings.My absolute favorite part of this game that got me hyped were the ingenious music levels, where every action int he level is set to the beat and rhythm of a song, remixed in a very special way for each world's music level. Though there's only a handful of music levels in the game, I feel like this isn't a bad thing as each music level plays out fantastically. The look of sheer joy on my face when I realized that the song playing in the level Castle Rock was a Rayman style remix of "Black Betty" is something I can never forget. And although the music levels are seen as the biggest selling point of Rayman Legends, Ubisoft went the extra mile to ensure that they put effort in all of the levels, and used the music levels as a lure for players, which makes the game that much richer in the experience.In terms of story, I'm willing to forgive Rayman Legends for its very basic storyline. Rayman games never exactly had a great story to them, and the fact that there's no set canon of the Rayman games just adds to the charm, which this game is chock full of. The basic goal of the game seems to intertwine itself with the individual stories that come along with each of the worlds.The Challenges and Kung Foot modes of the game add a bit more of a competitive side to Rayman Legends. Competing in different challenges every day and week for a chance to be seen at the top of the leaderboards is very nice, but I feel the PC version's Challenge mode is sort of sullied with the rise of many cheaters, especially in timed Challenges. I don't consider timed Challenges of any sort to be very serious on the PC version as people just cheat to get sub 10-second times as opposed to the people who actually have skill and talent in the game. Lum collection and Distance endurance challenges are just fine though as it's very hard to seem like one's cheating at these challenges as they can be done at one's own pace.I don't have any experience with Kung Foot though as I haven't had the chance to play this game with multiple people.In conclusion, this game is absolutely fantastic. Rayman Legends is a damn good example of how to make an excellent sequel to a good game. Legends builds upon the foundation and base of the original Rayman Origins and addresses many other issues that Origins had and aims very high to correct them. I would certainly say that Rayman Legends is much better than Origins, despite Origins also being an excellent game in its own right.Oh, as an additional warning, you have to make a separate U-Play account in order to play the game from Steam, which I honestly find annoying and a little pointless.Overall I'd give this game a 10/10

Posted: October 12, 2013
												This game is excellent; buy it....Oh, you're still here? You mean to tell me that you need reasons to buy things? Okay then.Rayman Legends is the best platformer of this decade. Everything in it has such a touch of affection and detail that it constantly wows the player with it's unique style. Common background elements could have been hung in an art exhibit, enemies interact and animate in a variety of ways that boggles the mind that a team of animators took the time for such a trivial thing. And its platforming is exceptionally tight. The game ramps up in its difficulty in such a way that near the end you're more than prepared for its Lost Levels echelon of difficulty. It hearkens back to the older days of platforming, while at the same time discarding old standards like lives and poor checkpointing. It's constant fun, not tedium. Rayman Legends is what a modern Mario game should have been, and it surpasses the old bastions of platforming on every front.And the music, sweet potato the music. When this game rolled out its series of trailers I was worried that it was just rehashing the songs of the previous title. But no, no no no. Another clever rouse on their part. There was a moment, I think around the third world, where I just had to put the controller down and appreciate how they had integrated the music into the stage. It's that good. In Origins the special stages were exceptionally difficult, particularly the Tricky Trunk levels. While Legends is no cakewalk, the trunk levels have been superseded by musically timed levels. It's understandably strange to jump and hit to the tune of Eye of the Tiger, but not unwelcome. But there's more than just those special stages, there's a huge variety of levels that leave the player with a myriad of options, all fun. There's a Gradius clone with mosquito mounts, time trials, wall running, a whole host of others.There are criticism, and if you've made it this far into this recommendation I guess I could give them to you. The game has the same problem as its predecessor in that once you've collected all the baubles and creatures, there's really nothing else for you to do than the multiplayer stuff or to farm for days to unlock a skin for your character. Once you complete the main story, all that's really left is tying up loose ends, and it feels a little lacking in reason either than tying up loose ends in this game is still quite fun. Also, the introduction of touch based gaming in the series has been replaced by button prompts. Unless you're playing on a system that utilizes the touch, then some of the Murphy levels feel cheating, as entire swaths of gameplay get replaced by hitting the Y button.But these are minor peeves. The game is still fun. It's a labor of love, and it shows it, bleeds it. I think, if you have the opportunity, that Rayman Legends is really worth your time.

												WARNING: uplay DRM, may the creators of it burn in hell.I find myself at a loss of words here. The game is so amazing I don't know how to even convey my impressions, which are positive in every possible way. The game has everything you would want from a sequel to Rayman Origins: a lot of levels full of crazy platforming, fun challenges and smooth difficulty curve, beautiful art style which manages to blend parallax 2D sceneries with 3D bosses perfectly, and the music which is not only amazing on its own, but fits the style of the game perfectly and highlights the crazyness of the action. The game even has a good share of levels from Rayman Origins added as a bonus, reworked to feel like a part of the new game experience (even those annoying mosquito levels aren't annoying anymore).And yes, Rayman Legends has its amount of re used assets from Rayman Origins, both graphics and sound wise, but it is still an astonishing game with a lot of new good stuff added to the mix.All in all: well designed, well executed and damn compelling.

Posted: March 22, 2014
												Rayman Legends is a game that has got a lot of attention everywhere. And it defintely deserves to be regraded highly among the gaming enthusiasts. Its a platformer, and more than that, its the most complete platformer I have ever come across. Its got collectibles and lots of little medals and stuff but most of them are achievable, they are not insanely tough to get or anythinng. The graphics are cute, fresh and interesting. The controls are reallly tight, as should be in a good platformer. The difficulty is not insanely tough( not atleast in the beginning) and every single level seems self-sufficient, in terms of its length, difficulty and number of collectibles. It is also a pretty long game, especially for a platformer but if you play a bit every now and then, it does not feel frustratingly long or overburdening in terms of gameplay. The game is so much fun you wont ever realise there are no steam achievements. There is so much to do within the game itself, that you dont feel like you miss out on achievements. I pretty much love this game and, for anyone who likes platformers, this is undoubtedly the game of the year.Much recommended to everyone.

												Rayman Legends is my favorite platformer.The platforming feels a lot more natural than most 2d games I've played (thinking of SMB and Mario), every world has a charming, unique style to it, and the musical levels at the end of each world are an absolute joy.A few parts felt obnoxiously difficult, but the game restarts very quickly after each death, so I never got frustrated.My one complaint is that the "8-bit" levels started to make me feel sick, but they only unlock after finishing the game and are easily ignored.

Posted: December 19, 2013
												Much like it's predecessor Rayman Origins, to me, this game is the epitome of sidescroller platforming.This game controls icredibily tightly, rarely was I left frustrated by wonky edge interactions and floaty controls, unlike the New Super Mario Bros franchise, and newer interation of the Donkey Kong Country game. I find that this is incredibly under-appreciated in the platformer genre these days; the reason Super Meat Boy was challengingly fun, rather than challengingly frustrating was because of it's incredibly tight controls that keep the game feeling fair and fluid, but demanding.The musical score is nothing short of incredible once again, with all the digeridoos and kazoos that are associated with the franchise, as well as excellent orchestral pieces.Visually the game is gorgeous and hilarious. It's just so great to see in motion, the animations are so slick and varied. The style is just so cohesive, like a modern looney toons. The one blatant exception to this are the 3d animated bosses. They really stick out like a sore thumb compared to the rest of the game, though they are good and fun in their own way.Level design is varied, the world themes are fantastic, and I never got the "ugh, I've had enough of this world/level" feeling I get in some other platformers. I did miss the 'Misquito' flying levels from the first game, but they are adequetly replaced by amazing Musically paced levels at the end of each world.What I didn't know going into this game, was that the 40 remasterd levels from the original are available through a scratch card unlockable-system. You've basically got a whole second game worth of content to play through (including some of those misquito levels I believe), if you didn't play through Origins the first time.If you're a fan of the sidescrolling platformer genre, this is a must play.

Posted: September 11, 2013
												If you like platformers, this game is a no-brainer. It is a complete and total upgrade to Rayman Origins, which is a great game itself. Pretty much everything that could have been improved, has been improved. The controls are really tight and I never encountered frustating or unfair passages in the game. The new cover songs-themed levels are really enjoyable and satisfying as well and I really wish the game had more of those. If you are not sure about buying the game, get Rayman Origins instead. It gives you a good idea of the game mechanics and it's a bit cheaper.However, Rayman Origins is not required to enjoy Legends, because there is no continuous story across games and a decent amount of levels from Origins are available to play in Legends.

Posted: June 27, 2015
												After having completed the unlockable content of the game and being just 30 Lums away from 100% completion, it's time to rate this game. What can I say...:It's the best freaking Jump'n Run ever (on Steam)!The artstyle, the gameplay, the character design, the music, the varying leveldesigns (rhythmbased, flight, speedrun, typical sidecroll levels etc)... It's so well-done, I can't think of anything the developers could have improved.The game has no online coop, but that is understandable, one little lagspike WILL kill you, because the more challenging levels are hell. At least the couch coop is absolutely great and makes the game more challenging (prepare to be trolled).Don't even bother trying to get the gold medals in leaderboard extra challenges, it's impossible!One important info: If you are a fan of the series like I am; Rayman Legends' best levels (I played them all on Wii) are also available in this game besides other unlocks which I won't spoil.One minus point for obligatory UPlay, but still a big recommendation; even Snoop Dogg likes it! ^^9/10

Posted: November 23, 2015
												Other than the required U-Play cancer, this game is pretty superb. It's hard to put in words how highly I praise this game. The level design is near perfect for a classical platformer. This, paired with great music, art design, and controls, results in one of the best platforming titles of this generation.  Not counting the gameplay, my favorite part of Legends is how the game is broken up into worlds (which, in itself, is a design choise dating back to 1985, but I digress).  Each world has its own theme and model swap of enemies, making each chapter seem like a new game; even though these are losely connected into the over-arching story, they have their own, subtle sub-plots.Up to this point, I've only mentioned the gameplay in passing, mostly because there's not much to criticize about it. Rayman handles like you would expect him to (most of the time) and never feels too stiff.  At times, Legends can be a little on the easy side, mostly because you have unlimited lives and frequent checkpoints, but is balanced out by the difficulty of the secondary objectives. This game is great for completionists, and you can put a good amount of time into grinding out the last few unlockable cosmetic characters that you wouldn't otherwise have by just completing the game.I don't have a good place in this review to mention the musical levels, but they're pretty fun and a nice change of pace.  Ubisoft also posts daily and weekly challenges with worldwide scoreboards, if you're into that sort of thing. 9/10, would recommend in a second.

Posted: April 3, 2015
												When the demo for this game came out I played it over and over again, especially the music level with a version of black betty which adds Kazoos! I racked up over three hours on the demo alone so i was pretty excited when I started playing the full game. If you have played the first version (origins) then you know what i mean when i say that this game is 'slap happy'.  The whole thing feels like one of those cartoons that makes you think that the animators were on LSD. the colors just pop from the screen and i could not help but smile and even screech in delight as a slapped kicked and whacked the living daylights out of enemies which are actually more fun and outlandish than the main characters, and that's really something! this game takes the WTH factor from origins and turns it up to eleven, expect to be surprised and delighted by EVERY. SINGLE. LEVEL! It's the small things that make this game fun, the way a venus flytrap sounds like a music box winding up or how the frogs mumble chords from ride of the valkeries as the plummet towards your hero. this game is truely a delight! However the experience is somewhat soured by the inaccuracy of murphy, the character from the wiiu version that makes some of the levels somewhat fustrating, using a gamepad does ease the fustration somewhat however.all in all this game gets a 9.5 out of 10, 8 out of 10 if you cannot stand u-play.

Posted: January 20, 2014
												Fantastic platformer that makes Rayman Origins obsolete. The mechanics have been changed for the better in my opinion combine that that a large amount of level from Origins are in this game, all of them redone with the new mechanics, makes me feel ripped of for having paid even more for Origins than I did for this game during the Steam Holiday Sale. Presentation is fantastic and even though I have not unlocked one yet, I played one of the music levels which was fantastic, like Bit Trip Runner but with Rayman Art and Rock music and some very good level design. For the masochists, the games levels progress to what i assume are insanely hard with a 6 skull rating. For the collectors, every level has two sets of trophies to earn more Teensies, which is effect is the currency used to unlock more levels, along with Lums which is the currency you earn in levels and other places that are used to buy new characters, and even on top of that there is an awesomeness ranking which I forget how you earn, but is used to unlock daily chalanges, of which there are up to 4 each day where you compete with poeple all over the world to see who is the best, and as you can figure these levels are different every day. Though similar to other levels already in the game, it still incrases the overall content and replayability of this game. For someone like who play it very casually, you can still run into the same problem that I ran into with Origins which was that I reached a point at which i had to redo previous levels to unlock more levels. This is less annoying in Legends because there are multiple story arcs, and so it means i wont feel as bad not finishing the game as I did with Origins because I wanted to finish the story. In the end the game is wonderful and gives you many ways of earning progress, including the reaffle mechanic (even though the interface for it was clearly made with the Wii U in mind).

Posted: March 17, 2015
												After playing Rayman Origins, I didn't think this sequel would to live up to the fun I had with that game, and it didn't.... It exceeded it! I love this game from beginning to end. It bring all the wacky traditional fun platforming I had with the last game and enhance it. The music is great and the stages are just gorgeous, honestly I didn't think they would top some of their over the top levels in Origins but they made those look mediocre by comparison. Not to mention how every world end with a musical level is just spectacular.Story:The story is just as confusing as last time, you know what it hard to even gather a story. Who cares! Bad guys are doing bad things, platform your way to victory and stop them! It work for Mario after all. Gameplay:Fast pace platforming that goes from easy to insanely difficult. But despite that there will never be a point you just say enough. You want to keep trying for the better score or fastest time to complete a stage. With the addition of a daily/weekly challenges, you can compete against other people for the fastest times or biggest score. Sound:Some of the best music I heard in a game. Honestly I could listen to all the songs from the musical levels of each world all day long. This games does what a sequel should do, top the prequel. In fact it relish in it by letting you go back and play the classic stage from each world in Origin. Honestly between all the characters to unlock, time/race challenges of each level, the Origins levels, creatures to collects, Scratch off tickets to win, and why am I still typing? I gotta play this game some more!

												Really good platformer that shows an amazing amount of effort put forward both artistically and level designs. The music is fantastic, topped off only by having a few special levels that revolve around the music. The game is packed with a lot of fun and a lot of laughs, I love Origins and Legends is certainly a worthy sequel with a lot of charm to it. Other platformers certainly seem to have gotten lazy with their games, where one would struggle to know which one is which if they didnt' see the title screen. This one shows effort and is worth the buy. I cannot reccomend this game enough if you like platformers whether it be Sonic, Mario, Commander Keen,  previous Rayman titles etc. It's a great co-op and solo game and don't worry unlike the New Super Mario Bros games, you do not bounce off eachother, you actually have moves to help. You can slap one another ...but, if used right it can actually save your butt. It's worth noting both Rayman Legends and Origin are worth having together, there are SOME levels from Origins you unlock in Legends. But there's a lot of fun to have with both- so get on it! DRM NOTE:This game requires Uplay to launch, which is incredibly irritating. On top of steam a mini-Uplay client needs to boot and often you'll find yourself waiting for Uplay to update before you get a chance to play your game. This counter productive move really ruins the whole idea of steam keeping games up to date when Ubisofts -DRM ontop of DRM- has to update seperately so it can triple check you're not a thief. This is of course is only highlighing my frustration when you know there's pirates playing this who do not have to sit through any of this and just enjoy the game that they didn't pay for but I did.

Posted: September 14, 2013
												Just buy this game, seriously, it's a work of art. To anybody who thought that the 2D Platformer was dead, this game is for you. Mario still has the 2D platformers, but in all honesty, they're stale, and Nintendo doesn't try anything new with them anymore, Rayman however, still manages to stay fresh after all these years, especially in this game. It takes Rayman Origins and flips it on its head. You'll experience such a mix of emotions while playing this, awe in how gorgeous the graphics and music are, laughing at the game's funny set up, and angry at how difficult the levels are.

Posted: September 23, 2014
												A beautifully rendered platformer, with an exquisite soundtrack, and exciting worlds, challenging single-player, baffling co-op... typical Rayman awesomeness. It refines the way Rayman Origins handled, resulting in a much more satisfying game to play than the occasionally slippery original. Honestly, there's little to criticize - Rayman, as a series, has an infectious optimism and joy, and Rayman Legends has it in spades; the music, characters, collectables - everything contributes to an atmosphere of happiness and fun. The only problem is that it's a game developed for the Wii U. And, nothing against the Wii U, the unique control system that influenced a lot gimmicky levels in this installment does not translate well to PC. Neither does Ubisoft's proprietary Uplay system, which is insultingly tacked on and is required to be open to play. Rayman Legends is, thankfully, a game awesome enough to overcome being a Wii U ex-pat and a Uplay software. Any other project would likely be irrepairably tarnished for it.

Posted: December 19, 2013
												Much like it's predecessor Rayman Origins, to me, this game is the epitome of sidescroller platforming.This game controls icredibily tightly, rarely was I left frustrated by wonky edge interactions and floaty controls, unlike the New Super Mario Bros franchise, and newer interation of the Donkey Kong Country game. I find that this is incredibly under-appreciated in the platformer genre these days; the reason Super Meat Boy was challengingly fun, rather than challengingly frustrating was because of it's incredibly tight controls that keep the game feeling fair and fluid, but demanding.The musical score is nothing short of incredible once again, with all the digeridoos and kazoos that are associated with the franchise, as well as excellent orchestral pieces.Visually the game is gorgeous and hilarious. It's just so great to see in motion, the animations are so slick and varied. The style is just so cohesive, like a modern looney toons. The one blatant exception to this are the 3d animated bosses. They really stick out like a sore thumb compared to the rest of the game, though they are good and fun in their own way.Level design is varied, the world themes are fantastic, and I never got the "ugh, I've had enough of this world/level" feeling I get in some other platformers. I did miss the 'Misquito' flying levels from the first game, but they are adequetly replaced by amazing Musically paced levels at the end of each world.What I didn't know going into this game, was that the 40 remasterd levels from the original are available through a scratch card unlockable-system. You've basically got a whole second game worth of content to play through (including some of those misquito levels I believe), if you didn't play through Origins the first time.If you're a fan of the sidescrolling platformer genre, this is a must play.

Posted: November 28, 2013
												Rayman Legends is a very fun game to play. Much fun as Origins. When I first saw the gameplay demo on youtube in 2012 I was so hyped. I know I never owned any other Rayman game(Excluding Origins)   back then,but when I gazed my eye on this game I wanted it. So when the game went on sale, I got my handy dandy Mann Co. keys and traded them for a copy.  The game has good controls and gorgeous art. If you play games on a keyboard, playing this game at first with a keyboard can be hard but you soon get used to it. The game can be also used with a controller(even Xbox or Playstation). The favorite part I like about this game are the Musical levels(Which includes reamkes of Black Betty, Woohoo, etc...) its very fun and I would always play those levels every time I go on. The game also features online challanges which involves obstacle runs and time trials. You win from Bronze to Diamond cups and it also feature the multiplayer minigame Kung Foot which is a form of soccer game. The downside to this game is that is the fact that it doesn't have online co-op and only has local co-op. The other downside (Which I really hate) is the ♥♥♥♥ing UPlay. Every Ubisoft game you buy, you have to make an UPlay account in order to play the game. You even have to make a Uplay account to play the demo. It sucks. It really does.  But back to the subject. Rayman Legends is a fun game I would recommend this game if you like fun, challanging levels. Even if you don't own any Old Rayman game. Just don't expect the online co-op thing like I said if you do plan on getting it.

Posted: December 24, 2013
												An absolutely brilliant game: in terms of pure gameplay, not much compares. It's high-paced and essentially very simple, but the inclusion of challenges and collectables add a layer of sophistication.Rhythm runs right at the heart of Rayman - a perfect level run is a beautiful, flowing experience. Very satisfying when you get it right, exhilierating when you crack the challenge levels, and constantly entertaining. And the musical  levels which end each "world" are just top-class, a welcome reward for your efforts. 10/10.Worth noting, though, that you have to run the game through UPlay, which is an intolerable piece of bloatware which does nothing but slow the game down. Not a game-changer, but certainly something which should be complained about.

												Before: Rayman Origins was just a flat canvas, painted well, the lively characters had simple, but very colorful detail, but that was just the beginning...After: Rayman Legends has little to some 3D relations visually, but really, all games must have a major 3D process one way or another, and the rest is sky rocketing 2D platforming that is so dazzling you'd can't keep you limbless hands off it.What You'll Get: Ultimate shading, lighting, particles, physics, challenges, for a Personal Computer version, it can be difficult, it is a pop-up book wonderland that is ready to be explored, .What you will be doing: Rescuing Teensies to rocking out on the castle roofs and wondering if someone is still mocking Mr. Dark's ego, or possibly playing the role as the roping up dames and placing them on train tracks kind of villain...? No doubt, this game should 100% be in your library!

												Rayman Legends = Legendary game+ Beautiful graphics+ Varied level design+ Good music+ Lots to unlock+ Decent controls+ Multiplayer+ Replayability- Cheaters/ hackers on multiplayer scoreboards- Some unlockable characters are similar (Barbara)I struggled to come up with negatives for this game as it is probably the best platform game I have played. This game is Very fun, very addictive, and a beautiful work of art.10/10Treat yourself ;)

Posted: March 17, 2015
												After playing Rayman Origins, I didn't think this sequel would to live up to the fun I had with that game, and it didn't.... It exceeded it! I love this game from beginning to end. It bring all the wacky traditional fun platforming I had with the last game and enhance it. The music is great and the stages are just gorgeous, honestly I didn't think they would top some of their over the top levels in Origins but they made those look mediocre by comparison. Not to mention how every world end with a musical level is just spectacular.Story:The story is just as confusing as last time, you know what it hard to even gather a story. Who cares! Bad guys are doing bad things, platform your way to victory and stop them! It work for Mario after all. Gameplay:Fast pace platforming that goes from easy to insanely difficult. But despite that there will never be a point you just say enough. You want to keep trying for the better score or fastest time to complete a stage. With the addition of a daily/weekly challenges, you can compete against other people for the fastest times or biggest score. Sound:Some of the best music I heard in a game. Honestly I could listen to all the songs from the musical levels of each world all day long. This games does what a sequel should do, top the prequel. In fact it relish in it by letting you go back and play the classic stage from each world in Origin. Honestly between all the characters to unlock, time/race challenges of each level, the Origins levels, creatures to collects, Scratch off tickets to win, and why am I still typing? I gotta play this game some more!

Posted: September 10, 2013
												WARNING: uplay DRM, may the creators of it burn in hell.I find myself at a loss of words here. The game is so amazing I don't know how to even convey my impressions, which are positive in every possible way. The game has everything you would want from a sequel to Rayman Origins: a lot of levels full of crazy platforming, fun challenges and smooth difficulty curve, beautiful art style which manages to blend parallax 2D sceneries with 3D bosses perfectly, and the music which is not only amazing on its own, but fits the style of the game perfectly and highlights the crazyness of the action. The game even has a good share of levels from Rayman Origins added as a bonus, reworked to feel like a part of the new game experience (even those annoying mosquito levels aren't annoying anymore).And yes, Rayman Legends has its amount of re used assets from Rayman Origins, both graphics and sound wise, but it is still an astonishing game with a lot of new good stuff added to the mix.All in all: well designed, well executed and damn compelling.

Posted: July 17, 2014
												When it comes to 2D platformers, Ubisoft has absolutely nailed everything; the controls, visuals, music, and everything else are top-notch in Rayman Legends. This game follows closely behind the formula of Rayman Origins. However, the phrase "If it ain't broken, don't fix it" really fits here. Rayman Legends takes what Origins did and refines it. There are noticeable improvements in some areas, and lots of minor gripes I had with Origins have been addressed in Legends. There are some  new creative level design ideas and elements that really helped set this game apart.This game is every bit as charming and fun as its predecessor. Both Rayman Origins and Legends make up some of the most creative, fun, and charming 2D platforming you'll ever get to experience. I highly recommend Rayman Legends to anyone who's enjoyed even a single 2D Mario game, or past 2D Rayman games.

Posted: July 18, 2014
												Definitely the best platform game I have ever played. Forget Mario, this is platforming at it's finest. I love the wacky characters and artwork. The level scenery is just beautiful. This has much more content than it's prequel, Rayman Origins, in fact including enhanced versions of multiple Rayman Origins levels. Also, there are even more costumes to earn, and the system for earning costumes has changed, instead requiring you to have a certain amount of Lums, as compared to having to save electoons in the previous installment. Highly recommend to ANY gamer, don't judge this game by its looks, play it and you'll see why this game is amazing

Posted: July 5, 2014
												One of the best platformers I have ever played and possibly WILL ever play.The inventive and clever level design made this just a joy to play through and without even realizing it I put around 50 hours in it and truth be told I'm probably going tp put in more.The music is fun and  can go from upbeat to dark and moody  and even touches on modern and retro stylings.I don't want to go into TOO much detail as finding all the little surprises in half the fun of playing this treasure of a game so if you are interested in this game or platformers I say pick it up. This game is amazing in every sense of the word and is just plain FUN.

Posted: July 21, 2014
												This game is fantastic.I'm not much of a platform gamer, but I grew up loving the crazy twisted world of the earthworm jim games, and many good games in the early eras of gaming were fairly platform-ish... but basically it's not been a focus for me.That said, this game really brought me back and drove home what a great experience the medium can provide.It's made by a team composed largely of the people behind the legendary game "Beyond Good and Evil" - if that's not enough to make you moist, you havent played that game, or you have no soul.It's dripping with character, and the art is wonderful and consistent, portraying a bizzare, slightly twisted but incredibly bright and joyful world, even in the darkest places. The music is phenomenal, with a wide variety of excellent tracks, including some that are reditions of songs you may be familiar with. What really got me was the well defined worlds and the sheer variety of gameplay mechanics. It seemed at times like every level was introducing a new mechanic, that may or may not be used in further levels - the path of the game is largely non-linear, with difficulty from level to level having little to do with its place in "order". It's most definately not a difficult game, it's a very easy to approach platformer, and you'll quickly learn the ins and outs of what they expect from you. Checkpoints are generally numerous, though the game does spice things up as you progress, there's even levels that have no checkpoints whatsoever and are just a long string of potential deaths - this initially was a source of frustration, but after completing my first level like this I couldnt deny that the sense of satisfaction gained by beating the whole thing flawlessly was well worth it, and I'm glad they had it.It's quite hard to really convey what's really best about this game, and that's the experience of playing it. It's just... fun!If there's a demo out, I'd reccomend giving it a go and seeing what you think. I cant imagine you not finding it worth your time and money though.For long term enjoyment, they have 2 daily and 2 weekly challenges, that are varied in type and setting. While I dont particularily like all of the challenges, they're mostly very enjoyable - the distance based ones, where you're falling down an infinate pit, running up an infinately falling tower, or running across a seemingly infinate level are my favourites, and you'll find yourself rated based on where you stand vs everyone else playing the challenges. You can see the ghost players of other people who have played the challenge who are close to your score, see the markers where they bite it, and generally it just feels solid... Oh yeah, and this game seems to include all the levels from the previous game, Rayman Origins, within the game, so you get 2 games for 1!As for negatives... hmmm... well there's one level left that I havent finished that's hard as♥♥♥♥♥♥ though I dont think that counts... Oh I've got one - there's a "creature" system, where you collect creatures occasionally when you beat a level, and they all go into a special room and once a day give out lums (the currency - which are these delightful little smiling bug things)  - and the system seems... pointless... you only get the monsters by beating levels, so you've basically beaten the game when you get them all, and the amount of lums they give is negligible compared to even just doing a normal level or challenge. Also the large number of alternate skins for barabara, the female character, are... a bit weird if not downright creepy or offensive at times. Barabara is the character I played as most due to the incredible character design, she's just brimming with a joyful michevious character that really fits the game, and she swings a mean axe... and rayman's kind of silly. But every world you enter has 2 alternate skins for barbara - the first one's pretty tame, but from then on it gets... odd.... There's barabara's that are sexualized (pronounced curves and cleavage) in appearance, and weirder still, when you die in this game you expand and then pop like a baloon - barbara's regular death is fairly normal... but there's 2 skins for her where you get a weirdass panty shot when she dies... it's... weird, man.But whatever, lets just blame it on them being french canadian. The game is absolutely phenomenal and any negatives I've encoutered, which are few, are greatly balanced out by the awesome.So yeah, try demo, get game, enjoy.

Posted: July 16, 2014
												Besides having to use another client (Uplay) after starting the game, the game itself is probably one of the most engrossing 2D platformers that I have ever played. Most of the stages are incredibly fun and amazingly drawn. The difficulty level may not be as difficult as origins but the fluidity of the levels makes up for it. Tons of unlockables and daily/weekly challenges invite replayability and the little details the developers put in the game (unique animations where you roll as you land and crouch at the same time, etc.) really show. If you ever encounter this game during a steam sale, definitely consider buying it.

												Oh my god. This ♥♥♥♥ing game. Holy♥♥♥♥♥♥..Oh my god..I can't begin to describe how much in love I am with this game. Running up walls onto ceilings and then preforming a sweet ground pound on an enemy below to have an explosion of lums fly into your collection. There is tons of trial and error at times, but I didn't find myself getting too annoyed, or at all, actually. It's a really fair game. It honestly reminds me of the classic Donkey Kong Country series with the toughness of the game. Posted: May 28, 2014
VERDICT Buy Now (9.6/10)Completion Time: 20-25 hoursBottom Line: "This game is quite simply the best. Rayman is at it again"PROS+Level Design+Level Variety+SO MANY LEVELS+Really pretty+Hilarious+Awesome Music+Replay Value+The CreditsCONS-No Online Co-op-Uplay integration-The game endsREVIEWThis game is quite simply the best. Rayman is at it again as he traverses 80 creative and often hilarious levels to save the world from nightmares. You'll be swimming, flying, transforming and more through 8 incredibly stylish and unique worlds. With each level you will surely be trying something new, with a huge variety of gameplay mechanics involved. Level designs are incredibly fun and fast paced, including musical levels where your actions are synchronized with the music. While we're on this topic, the score is awesome. There is everything from tropical ukulele driven tunes to stealthy James Bond-esque ballads. Did I mention this game is really pretty? Especially the remastered throwback levels where the detail is immense.Don't even get me started on replay value. Not only are there 120 levels to master, but in each there are plenty of collectables and secret areas. Online challenges also ensure the introduction of fresh new content EVERY DAY. Finally, the ending includes the most creative credits sequence I have ever seen. Never have credits been so much fun.There are only two minor gripes I have with the game. There is no online multiplayer co-op, and there is Uplay integration, meaning you must create a Ubisoft account in order to start the game. Otherwise this game is absolutely brilliant.

Posted: May 24, 2016
												Loads of fun, especially playing couch co-op with friends.  I loved Rayman Origins, and I'm tempted to say this is the better game, overall.  The level design is both more creative and flows a lot better than Origins, even when it was at its best.  I'm also glad they replaced the time-trial challenges for each level with specific speed-run challenge levels.  My least favorite part of Origins were those timed runs -- the base levels really weren't designed for speedrunning, so trying to beat them in a set time limit without dying was more awkward and frustrating than challenging or fun.  The speed-run challenge levels here are short and play almost like platforming rhythm puzzles.  Speaking of rhythm -- the music levels are amazing!  By far the most memorable part of the game, and they add a lot of anticipation as you work to unlock them.  It's also one of the most beautiful games I've ever played.  The special effects, shaders, and 3D assets meld perfectly with the overall 2D aesthetic.  I wish more games looked and played this well!

Once you create an account with them (Uplay) in order to get the game started you have to have a game key. Well to save you some time and aggravation, once you have downloaded the game look underneath your DLC and youll see that the game key has been installed and then cick on that to copy the game key to the Uplay window that prompts you for said game key. Then you should be good to go. Im new to that whole process with having to download a game like that, so it might have been the obvious thing to do but for someone who has never had to do anything like that before it was aggravating. Posted: September 10, 2013
												WARNING: uplay DRM, may the creators of it burn in hell.I find myself at a loss of words here. The game is so amazing I don't know how to even convey my impressions, which are positive in every possible way. The game has everything you would want from a sequel to Rayman Origins: a lot of levels full of crazy platforming, fun challenges and smooth difficulty curve, beautiful art style which manages to blend parallax 2D sceneries with 3D bosses perfectly, and the music which is not only amazing on its own, but fits the style of the game perfectly and highlights the crazyness of the action. The game even has a good share of levels from Rayman Origins added as a bonus, reworked to feel like a part of the new game experience (even those annoying mosquito levels aren't annoying anymore).And yes, Rayman Legends has its amount of re used assets from Rayman Origins, both graphics and sound wise, but it is still an astonishing game with a lot of new good stuff added to the mix.All in all: well designed, well executed and damn compelling.

Posted: December 2, 2013
												I don't know how I feel about this game. Origins, the predecessor to this game, had a clear focus design wise and simple world progression. Legends has needlessly complicated things by adding fluff that distracts you from the juicy core of the game, much like what hats do for Team Fortress 2. Scratch cards, leader boards, animals, and a currency system based on lums (glowing flies you collect in levels). Couple this together with the dodgy adaptation of Wii U tablet stuff made to work with controllers and you end up with a game that is a bit of a mess. Legends would be a much better game if Ubisoft just trimmed off the fat. But the joy found in Origins is still here under all this pointless flubber. There is still game here that is fun and worth your time, even if you have to wade through the muck to get it.

Posted: December 7, 2013
												Rayman Legends is a game bursting with charm, fantastic level design, amazing visuals and content. As a game this game constantly made me smile more than any other game I ever recall playing (and this is based on 20 years worth of experiences) the are very few games I'd call perfect but Rayman Legends is THE perfect 2D platformer, if you have ever enjoyed a 2D Platformer you SHOULD buy this.

Posted: December 19, 2013
												Much like it's predecessor Rayman Origins, to me, this game is the epitome of sidescroller platforming.This game controls icredibily tightly, rarely was I left frustrated by wonky edge interactions and floaty controls, unlike the New Super Mario Bros franchise, and newer interation of the Donkey Kong Country game. I find that this is incredibly under-appreciated in the platformer genre these days; the reason Super Meat Boy was challengingly fun, rather than challengingly frustrating was because of it's incredibly tight controls that keep the game feeling fair and fluid, but demanding.The musical score is nothing short of incredible once again, with all the digeridoos and kazoos that are associated with the franchise, as well as excellent orchestral pieces.Visually the game is gorgeous and hilarious. It's just so great to see in motion, the animations are so slick and varied. The style is just so cohesive, like a modern looney toons. The one blatant exception to this are the 3d animated bosses. They really stick out like a sore thumb compared to the rest of the game, though they are good and fun in their own way.Level design is varied, the world themes are fantastic, and I never got the "ugh, I've had enough of this world/level" feeling I get in some other platformers. I did miss the 'Misquito' flying levels from the first game, but they are adequetly replaced by amazing Musically paced levels at the end of each world.What I didn't know going into this game, was that the 40 remasterd levels from the original are available through a scratch card unlockable-system. You've basically got a whole second game worth of content to play through (including some of those misquito levels I believe), if you didn't play through Origins the first time.If you're a fan of the sidescrolling platformer genre, this is a must play.

												Man, this game..Rayman Legends remains (together with Rayman Origins) THE best platformer of the last 10 years, hands down.The mechanics are incredible and very responsive, the whole game feels very polished (I encountered ZERO bugs with this game, and I played this game a lot! Posted: July 3, 2015
												I really love this platformer game.  The levels are challenging but not impossible, and makes the right choice to have there be varying rewards based on how well you do, rather than make every level a pass/fail.One of the best parts of it is that there's no real penalty for dying.  Other players can just shoot you, and you're back.  This means that I can play it with my 5 year old and 7 year old, and we all have fun.  Sure, I'm getting most of the lums, but they're having a blast, too.I'm not as big a fan of the challenges.  They're repetitive, and I felt like I was grinding out my million lums by the end.  There's also the problem that there are so many cheaters that a platinum result in the challenges is basically impossible, so it makes it an even longer grind.By far the biggest problem, though, is the lack of multiple saves.  I couldn't play my own game, and then start over again with my kids.  If you want to start over, you need to delete your entire save.  That means multiple people can't really have their own games.  It's a huge flaw, and something the first game didn't do.Score: 8.5/10

Posted: August 23, 2015
												Rayman Legends (Orgins) This was always a classic for me considering I first played Rayman on the PS1 as a kid. Awesome platform that always caught my attention. I'm glad to see Rayman has been remade for the PC.This game has no graphic options at all but it doesn't need it because its a 2D platform with amazing graphics and art design. It's very well programmed and the colors are eye catching and beautiful. The characters in the game of course is Rayman and now you can unlock Hero's to play which feels slightly different then playing Rayman. Each hero has many skins to unlock as well. The enemys are well desgined and some look really epic and deadly. The controls are simple. I use a USB 360 controller of course and the game's physics and mechanics are not difficult to figure out and is actually programmed rather well. The movement is simple and basic but yet one wrong move equals instant death. Game is playable to a 5 year old but becomes difficult enough for an adult while a child can still enjoy the difficulty as the game progresses. The platforms are awesome and the levels are super creative its almost genius. Lots of hidden secrets in every level. There are so many levels to play and unlock its insane how much work was put into the length of the game. You simply cannot get bored but many breaks will be taken. The sound effects are neat. While the music really sells it for me. There is also an online type challenge everyday and one that lasts 7 days. You compete for the Bronze, Silver or Gold cup. Which is great if you like a good challenge.I'm running this game on an AMD ASUS Sabertooth 990 FX, AMD 8-Core, 16gb Ram, Nvidia GT 750 2gb LP. Windows 7 no issues at all running this game or any crashes. Yes this game does require Uplay which I wasnt a fan of awhile back but who cares it doesnt hurt anything having it installed just don't use it as a main client. Keep using Steam. Uplay only launches when you launch a game that requires Uplay. After you done playing close it. Steam still records your hours played however Uplay is where your achievments are unlocked and recorded unfortunatly. This shouldn't stop you from enjoying the game though. It's worth the time and effort. I purchased during the Steam Summer sale for 12$ org price was $29.99. It also included Rayman Orgins for 3$ I believe which was an absolute steal. Highly recommend buying this game. If you can wait buy it during a steam event.Overall 10/10Look up some gameplay on youtube just to see the greatness Rayman has to offer. :)
